TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, did the Prime Minister state point‐blank on AM this morning when discussing nursing homes: `I wouldn't expect it to be changed again, no, because the changes we have made represent the finetuning I promised before I left Australia.' Is it not a fact, however, that in parliament yesterday Minister Smith flagged his desire for further change and indicated in his press release that he may make further adjustments? Can you please clarify these mixed messages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for her question. I am happy to clarify those messages which Senator Neal considers mixed; they are not mixed at all. The Prime Minister made perfectly clear that the fundamentals would not change: the bonds will be paid; no-one will be forced to sell their home; that no-one now in a nursing home or hostel will be affected; that people who can afford it should contribute to the cost of their care—and Senator Neal should take particular note of that, because both of them have said that—that the taxpayer subsidises nursing homes and hostels by $2,600 million a year at present; and the only alternative to user pays is more tax at a time when the taxpayer base is shrinking.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said repeatedly, with the ageing of the population, the taxpayer base is shrinking dramatically. They are the only alternatives. So there is no mixed message whatever. It is interesting that Senator Neal comes in with these questions trying to highlight certain things. For example, she asked yesterday—and I will be tabling the answer at the end of question time:

BREAK.PARA: . . . can you tell us how much the government spent on printing the failed version of the child‐care forms . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Do you believe it is in order for Senator Herron to so obviously stray from the question asked today by Senator Neal to a question that was asked yesterday by Senator Neal? It is proper for the minister—who yet again could not answer a question directed to him about nursing homes—to table the answer after question time, but I am sure you would agree with me that it is not in order for him to canvass that issue so directly in answer to this question today.

—Madam President, on the point of order: the point that I was making is relevant to the question because it is the same analogy that Senator Neal made yesterday about which I am answering a question today. I think it is relevant because I was going to make the point in relation to that question. I will certainly table the answer at the end of question time, but it is relevant to the answer that I am giving now.
—Perhaps you should leave out the reference to yesterday's question and just deal with today's question, Senator.

—Thank you, Madam President, but if a question was asked yesterday about what it would cost to pulp some sort of imaginary thing, the answer would be nil because it did not occur. The point I am making is that there is no disparity between the two statements. The basic principles stand: no person in a nursing home or a hostel will be affected; and bonds will stay in place. So there is no disparity between what the Prime Minister said and what the minister said yesterday.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say that I am at a loss to understand how the Prime Minister's saying that there will be no change and the minister's saying that there will be change is not contradictory. Obviously Senator Herron is not going to answer that question. Maybe he can answer this question: will you guarantee on this occasion, after these changes, that no Australian will have to sell their family home in order to pay the bond for a nursing home?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Neal let the cat out of the bag by saying that she was going to ask a completely separate question. It is clearly not a supplementary and does not, in any shape or form, arise out of the subject matter of the first part of the question, which was a contrast between remarks made by Mr Smith and by the Prime Minister. Now we are being asked for a generalised guarantee on some other aspect of the issue. If it is good enough for this question to be allowed, then it is good enough for Senator Faulkner to sit there and cop it on a regular basis whenever we talk about the general subject matter.

—Madam President, on the point of order: I would have thought that, if Senator Herron felt it was appropriate to range as widely in his answer as he did in relation to issues such as child care, it is perfectly appropriate for Senator Neal to ask a supplementary question in relation to whether Senator Herron will give the Senate—and, for that matter, the people of Australia—a guarantee that no Australian will have to sell their family home in order to pay the bond for a nursing home bed. I put it to you, Madam President, that not only is it in order; it certainly deserves an answer.

—It is within the wide range from which supplementary questions have been allowed—well beyond what is in fact a supplementary question, but that has occurred in recent times. If Senator Herron has anything to add, he may do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I said previously, and I will repeat it—because it was not acknowledged on the other side—that no‐one will be forced to sell their home.
—Give the guarantee or sit down.
—My question is to Senator Hill.
—Guarantee that. You are not guaranteeing that.
—Order! Senator Cook, cease interjecting in that fashion.

—In view of the crisis in the currencies—a crisis which has now turned into a crisis in the economies of a number of South‐East Asian countries—what lessons can be drawn from the handling of the Australian economy by the Liberal government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important question. There is no doubt that our decision to reel in expenditure did cause and is still causing some electoral pain. Hard decisions by a government often do, but sometimes hard decisions are also absolutely necessary in the best interests of the total community. I can tell you, the decisions this coalition government took when it came to office to address the $10 billion deficit we inherited from Labor have turned out to be critically important.

ANSWER.PARA: In the difficult broader economic circumstances which have just been referred to, it is comforting to know that inflation in this country is now at a 35‐year low. As you know, the $10 billion deficit of Labor will be turned next year into a surplus—within three years the domestic deficit will be a domestic surplus. Last year we were able to repay debt, this year we have been able to repay debt and next year we will be able to repay debt, so that by the year 2000 the debt to GDP ratio will have halved to 10 per cent. Interest rates are now at their lowest in 20 years, housing is now 25 per cent more affordable than when Labor was in government, we have not had a speculative boom in relation to asset prices over recent times, problem loans in the banking system are historically low and business investment is at very high levels.

It is very important that we have an economy in which the fundamentals are right. It is on that basis that we are still seeing international writers say there are opportunities in Australia. I noted in the Herald Tribune of last weekend—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left—
—Why do you want communications, Cook?
—Senator Alston, cease shouting across the chamber in that fashion, and Senator Cook likewise.

—in its money section, it said, `Amid a stormy Pacific, Australia, an island of opportunity.' That is because the Howard government has taken the hard economic decisions and got the fundamentals right. And, I can tell you, at the moment most Australians are grateful that we took those hard decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: Contrast Labor. Where would we have been with Labor. We inherited a budget deficit spiralling out of control, Commonwealth debt ballooning out of control—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Persistent and wilful interjections will not be tolerated. They are not even interjections to the question. They are just deliberate disruption of question time and totally disorderly.

—We can understand the embarrassment of Labor. We inherited a massively increasing current account deficit which was out of control. Australians remember small business interest rates of 20 per cent under Labor, home interest rates of 17 per cent and credit card interest rates of 25 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting. There is an appropriate time to debate this issue, and it is not now.

—That was the legacy of Labor. That was what they were embarrassed about. Had it continued, debt by the year 2000 would have been $120 billion, an increase of 600 per cent over 10 years. What a legacy of Labor.

ANSWER.PARA: Even when we took the hard decisions to reduce the deficit, we were condemned by Mr Gareth Evans, the Labor Treasury spokesman. He argued against it. We were condemned by Mr Crean. Mr Crean said that if we cut the deficit it would force interest rates up. What economic nonsense. This opposition an nounced that it would oppose $7.3 billion of deficit cuts.

In other words, even when we were given the opportunity to govern by the Australian people, Labor said, `You are going in the wrong direction. Our old direction of high inflation, high deficit, high debt is the way to go.' Imagine where we would have been today if they had remained in government? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the statement by a former Labor minister who is in the chamber today, which says, in effect, that Australia is in the clear because of the steps taken by the Labor government? Is this the same former Labor minister, the same distinguished oracle who told us in 1995—and told the Australian public—that the Labor Party were about to deliver a budget surplus to us?
—Get your facts right.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give you the facts. Recorded in Hansard on 20 September 1995, Senator Cook, Labor's economic spokesman in this place, said:

ANSWER.PARA: But I tell you one thing for sure: our budget will be balanced and in surplus. Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus—

What happened? Within a few months we learnt that Labor was $10.3 billion in deficit. That shows the economic incompetence with which Labor governed this country, the mess that they got us into with high debt, high interest rates and high inflation. Thank goodness there is some decent economic handling of the economy these days.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, I refer to your statement in the Senate yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a fact that 40 per cent of people in nursing homes do not pay anything. . . They do not pay because they are fully pensionable.

Minister, isn't it true that fully pensionable nursing home residents in fact pay 85 per cent of their pension? Isn't it also true that, since 1 October this year, anyone with assets over $22,500 is liable to pay an accommodation bond? Minister, isn't this just one more case of your misleading the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement was made at the time and, as Senator Forshaw well knows, it was made in relation to the bonds. It was fairly obvious at the time that that was the context. Senator Forshaw, the percentage varies, as you know, according to the number. For example, the number of people in hostels, as at the beginning of this month, was 63,145 and the number in nursing homes was 74,406. With the changes that were announced yesterday, none of those people will be affected by any changes.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the charges, they were the charges, as Senator Forshaw well knows, that were introduced by the Labor government, and all that we have done is continue that. The changes that were introduced were in relation to nursing homes and the up‐front bonds. They are similar in principle to what the Labor Party introduced into hostels, and they are similar in principle to when people go into retirement villages, hostels or nursing homes. The principle is the same. So to allege that I have misled the Senate is totally incorrect. But I am not surprised at this sort of statement because the whole of the strategy of the opposition is to mislead, misinform, create smokescreens and make false statements which are entirely designed to upset older people in nursing homes and the proprietors of nursing homes—the people who are affected predominantly. That was the point I was making of the self‐funded retirees and people who contribute to upkeep in nursing homes. It is significant that that group said they were happy with the changes that the government was introducing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you should not be surprised at the statement because in fact they were your own words. They were your words yesterday. You stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a fact that 40 per cent of people in nursing homes do not pay anything. . . They . . . are fully pensionable.

Minister, can you advise the Senate how many of the 40 per cent of nursing home residents who are fully pensionable—and who, according to your statement, do not pay anything—have assets of over $22,500? Minister, will you again answer the question. Aren't you making those people pay an accommodation bond? In other words, you are making them pay something in addition to the percentage of the pension.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I will repeat that that statement was in relation to the payment of bonds, as Senator Forshaw well knows. In the supplementary question he asked how many people have assets above a certain figure. I have not got that in the brief in front of me. I will be happy to refer that to the minister so that we can find out if we can get a figure. It may be that it will be based on those that already are in hostels or in nursing homes, but I am happy to get back to Senator Forshaw if that is his desire.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. The minister will be aware that Minister Reith, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, has said that significant safety problems arise as a result of the seamen's engagement system under which the Maritime Union of Australia supplies all the seamen for vessels which supply our vital offshore oil and gas industry. Can the minister explain why this compromise of safety standards occurs? What needs to be done to rectify the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for that question. The government regards the health and safety of workers in our offshore oil and gas industry as being of paramount importance.
—That's not true.
—Senator Cook says that is not true. When we came into government, we inherited a very serious safety case problem.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, you have been interjecting persistently throughout question time today.
—As a result of that—yet another bad inheritance from the Labor Party—I appointed Dr Tony Barrell, an expert from the North Sea, to review Australia's safety case regime. Dr Barrell found:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . there are special safety problems inherent in the present roster system . . .
That is what Dr Barrell said.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is a conversation going on across the chamber which must cease. I am entitled to hear the answer that Senator Parer is giving.

—Currently the MUA, through the seamen's engagement system, supplies all the ratings for the supply vessels offshore and it is important that senators understand just how this system works. Firstly, a company is prevented from engaging a seafarer for use throughout its fleet. Commonly seafarers are allocated from ports, like Newcastle, to work on the North West Shelf, often for very short periods, and they are flown to work at company expense on full pay, including, of course, a stopover in Perth. The seafarers receive more than a day's holiday for each day they work, resulting in 28 weeks paid leave a year. For each day worked, they get 1.53 days off.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, cease interjecting.

—If you are interested in the health of these people and their safety, just listen to this: there is no adequate medical testing, which results in a compensation cost of 13 per cent of gross weekly earnings. Seafarers also get $50 a day just for being on the roster—not for working, just for being on the roster. Long‐service leave, clothing and other allowances are all centrally funded. The result is that in Australia's ships 66 per cent of operating costs are wage related. The international standard is 22 per cent, Senator O'Chee. Union rorting on this scale is bad enough but when it puts at risk the safety of crew members and people who work on the rigs it is totally intolerable.

ANSWER.PARA: The industry safety statistics indicate that crew engaged under the seamen's engagement system on offshore support vessels incur a disproportionately high accident rate in comparison to crew members. One in five seafarers lodged a worker's compensation claim last year. This is absolutely appalling and a direct result of the seamen's engagement system. This system results in the selection of crew members who are sometimes medically unsuitable for the demanding work that occurs offshore.

The previous government received report after report on this matter and, as in so many areas, did absolutely nothing. Mr Reith has said the government is prepared to take action on a number of other fronts in relation to the maritime industry. The government is not prepared to allow archaic work practices to prevent the implementation of modern and effective safety management systems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the government support the decision of the Swiss government to consider selling up to 1,400 tonnes of their gold reserves? Was your government's declaration of its lack of faith in holding gold by approving the RBA sale of 167 tonnes of gold a signal to other central banks, including the Swiss, that gold is no longer a strategic government reserve holding?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the question has been heard, but we want to hear the answer. Senators on both sides will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bishop for that comment. It is nice to see a Western Australian senator taking an interest in the mining industry. The reality is that the miners in Western Australia are looking to see how Senator Bishop votes on native title—on the Wik issue. That is what the miners in Western Australia are interested in. Their considerations are separate from the RBA's decision to sell part of its gold reserves. My understanding of the advice I have received is that an expert group in Switzerland established to look at sales of gold and other issues has recommended that changes be made to the Swiss constitution to enable sales of gold. The Swiss government will consider that report.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making a real mess of this one.

—Do you want an answer to the question or not? I am seeking to answer the question, but I have all this abuse coming from Senator Bogus now. The reality is that I am answering the question. It was an interesting question and I thought that Senator Bishop would be interested in the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: For the Swiss to undertake such sales requires two significant steps. Swiss law previously required 40 per cent of gold backing of their currency. However, legislation has been passed to reduce this to 25 per cent which is expected to come into effect on 1 November. This will allow lending, but at this stage the advice I have is not sales, of Swiss gold reserves.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, it is exceedingly difficult to answer this question because of the relentless abuse from Senator Faulkner and his other colleagues on the front bench. I am trying to answer Senator Bishop's question, but it is very difficult with all this noise and abuse coming from the Labor Party. I repeat that the Swiss constitution forbids the sale of their gold reserves and to change this would require a referendum.
—You ought to take your hand out of your pocket.
—Order! Senator Carr, that has absolutely nothing to do with the question.

—Madam President, the only way that Senator Carr can get any notice at all is to call out abuse from the Labor front bench. We know why Senator Carr has not been promoted; they know why he has not been promoted. Why doesn't someone tell Senator Carr why he has not been promoted? The answer is that he never makes a sensible contribution. Senator Bishop, my understanding is that to change this constitution would require a referendum, which is expected early in 1999.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that Senator Kemp has introduced the issue of the role of Western Australian senators, gold tax and the mining industry, I ask: in view of the collapse of the gold price and the introduction of the Liberal gold tax, will the government consider inserting section 23PA into the tax act to help struggling Western Australian gold prospectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you been following the debate on 23PA? Honestly, Senator Bishop finally emerges from nowhere and suddenly evinces some interest in the mining industry. As I said, he will be tested. We will be looking very closely at the way he votes on the Wik 10‐point plan.

ANSWER.PARA: The 23PA issue on mining rights has been debated very extensively in this chamber and extensive and constructive consultation has been carried out with the senators from Western Australia. I might say it is interesting that for the first time Senator Bishop has shown an interest in the mining industry, but I regret to say that his party has been a disaster for the mining industry. If he is really keen on the mining industry, let us wait and see how he votes on the 10‐point plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, I refer to your answer to a question I asked last Thursday about the Hinchinbrook development. In your answer you indicated that the development may not impact on the world heritage values of Hinchinbrook Channel or Hinchinbrook Island because, you said, `This development was further inland.' Are you aware of further press reports in which Mr Williams described the expansion as a marine industrial precinct and destined to become the boating mecca for North Queensland? Do you agree that such an expansion will impact on the channel and the island? Will you now take action to ensure that the world heritage values of the area are protected and that an environmental impact study on this expansion is carried out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to hear from Senator Woodley the basis upon which I can require that to be carried out. The piece of land, as I understand it, is not on the coastal strip; it is inland of the coastal strip. If I am wrong on that, Senator Woodley will correct me. But I think that is right, from the map I originally saw. It went to the Queensland government for planning approval, and that was given. As Senator Woodley knows, the Queensland government did not require further environmental assessments. From what I read, it did not require further assessments because it said that there had been adequate assessments in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue, I guess, is whether it will result in an increased aggregate number of visitors. Senator Woodley's figures that he read last week, I think, would suggest that it might increase the potential size of the resort from some 1,200 to 1,500. If that is so, there could be potentially a further 300.

Bearing in mind the extent of the studies we required last time, which we took into account—studies on the issue of whether this development would have any significant effect upon the world heritage values of the adjoining protected area—it is very difficult to see how an increase of that number would make any significant difference. That was the basis upon which I answered the question last week, and I have seen and heard nothing since that would cause me to revise that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, although it really does not take us any further than we were last Thursday. I did supply further information: `It is a marine industrial precinct and destined to become the boating mecca for North Queensland.' However, Minister, arising out of that answer, could I further ask you: did your office make inquiries to find out why the Queensland government did not see fit to consult you over this decision?

—I have just said that I understand the reasons for making the decision were that they believed that there had been adequate environmental assessments. I remind Senator Woodley that this is a Queensland state government planning process, not a Commonwealth process. I must say that to suggest this will become a marine industrial precinct and a boating—
—That's what Mr Williams said.

—Yes, but he has got some interest in promoting his development and I would suggest that that might be a fairly grand description of what Mr Williams has in mind. As I said, I have nothing before me that would suggest that there would be any additional burden upon nearby world heritage values as a result of this latest planning approval.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, do you recall that in your pre-election policy document Better Communications you made specific promises about sports anti-siphoning rules, digital terrestrial television, re‐transmission of free‐to‐air signals and Australian content rules relating to subscription television? Also, can you explain why it has taken you over two years to take decisions you claimed in January 1996 have already been taken in Better Communications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to get a question from someone who has not been able to get around to asking a question in this portfolio, I think, since May this year. He has been playing in the seconds, basically: nursing homes, defence, almost everything else. So I am delighted that Senator Ray has allowed you to get back onto the field just for once—a quick gallop.

ANSWER.PARA: I did see that very silly press release you put out the other day. I was tempted to have a bit of a whack at it, but I thought it was really hardly worth it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He called you a doormat.

—You have been trying to get that up for quite a while, but it has not got you anywhere, so I suggest you try some other approach. The discussions I had with ASTRA were along the lines of further work being required to be done. I do not know if you have, in fact, spoken to anyone who attended that meeting—and there is one person I can think of whom you may well have spoken to—but I have my doubts, because the last time you spoke to Lachlan Murdoch you managed to blurt it out all over the Financial Review . Have you been to see him since? I bet they would not even let you into the building, let alone his office, after that little effort.

ANSWER.PARA: What I did indicate to ASTRA—and ASTRA agreed—was that there was more work required to be done in a number of areas. These are not straightforward issues. I know they are beyond your comprehension, because the most you seem to be able to do is put out silly little press releases, trying to play politics, trying to come in on the margins, without ever addressing the solutions to very vexing problems like the anti-siphoning rules. I have no idea where you stand on the issue but it is quite clear that it is a complex matter that does require more work to be done. I am not prepared to rush in, as you may be, and simply try to score a cheap political point without ensuring that we have done all the necessary homework. In that and in a number of areas where I did have what I regard as confidential discussions I did make it clear that I would very much appreciate further information being provided on a number of those matters. I look forward to receiving that and, when that is to hand, we will be pursuing the issues, as we do, with our normal expedition.

There are only five left on the front bench, I notice, and you are one of them. So that speaks volumes for the quality of the talent. But if you really want to know something about some of these issues, come and see me any time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw to the minister's attention that this issue was written up recently in the Sydney Morning Herald .
—It must be true!

—Have you issued a writ against them? Of course you have not; you would not have the courage. I also point out, Minister, that all of these promises were listed in your document Better Communications of January 1996.
—Along with a lot of others.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

There are a multitude of issues that have required attention and we have been working systematically through the list. I was hoping that there might have been a time when you might have had a view that was constructive that might have added to the quality of the debate. But there has been such a deafening silence that I have had to do it all by myself. I am happy to persist on that basis. But, if you do ever want to get back into it, if you do want to put any submissions—we all remember that contribution you made to the ABC inquiry—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure, actually. After five attempts to block it, he then had the cheek to turn around and say, `I've got no objection after all.' —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and relates to the fact that 5,000 jobs, directly and indirectly, are being threatened by the dumping of coated paper into Australia from Asia and Europe. Is the minister aware that, for one reason or another, the Customs inquiry into dumping procedures has, inter alia, failed to properly investigate the cost to make and sell the goods under investigation and in most cases did not include any mill/production facility visits to verify costs; failed to ensure an independent third party inquiry to verify domestic prices in each country; failed to ensure examination of third country transactions to ascertain whether the producer under investigation was dumping into other markets; and did not provide investigating officers with sufficient time to properly undertake their tasks? What action does the minister intend to take to ensure that the Customs findings are not flawed by inadequate investigations? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has a commitment to maintaining an effective anti‐dumping regime and pledged during the 1996 election to improve anti‐dumping and countervailing procedures to ensure Australian producers were not disadvantaged. In June 1996, Mr Laurie Willett was appointed to head an external review to determine how best to implement the government's announced policy. Following that report, we have already announced a number of measures designed to improve the administration of dumping inquiries. The most important measure was to shorten the time frame for the investigation of dumping complaints by 30 days from 245 to 215 days. I point out that we now have the fastest system in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: On another front, the government has legislation before the parliament to amend the relevant dumping acts to deal with economies, such as China, that are in a transitional phase. TALK.START.PARA: —Senators Abetz and Ferris, by letter dated 27 October 1997, have raised with me a matter of privilege under standing order 81. The senators refer to circumstances which appear to indicate that there were disclosures of the report of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, not authorised by the committee, before the presentation of the report to either house of the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: They state that copies of the minority report of the committee were distributed, and journalists briefed on the minority report, before its presentation, and that the contents of it were disclosed at a press conference televised in Parliament House. I am required to determine whether a motion to refer a matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence having regard to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

A matter is given precedence if it is capable of meeting criterion (a) and there is no other readily available remedy. Unauthorised disclosure of committee documents is declared by standing order 37 and resolution 6 of the Senate's privilege resolutions to be a matter which may constitute a contempt of the Senate. Allegations of unauthorised disclosure of reports of committees have been regarded as serious matters meeting criterion (a) and instances have been investigated by the Privileges Committee in the past. Signatories of a minority report are not authorised to disclose it before its presentation; minority reports are not in any different category from other committee documents.

As I recently reminded the Senate, on 20 June 1996 the Senate adopted a recommendation of the Privileges Committee that, in cases of unauthorised disclosure of committee documents, the committee concerned should in the first instance inquire into the disclosure and determine whether it had a tendency substantially to interfere with the work of the com mittee or of the Senate. The resolution adopting this procedure, however, explicitly does not prevent a senator raising a matter of privilege under standing order 81 in the absence of such an inquiry and determination by the committee concerned.

The senators also suggest that the minority report discloses deliberations of the committee without its authorisation. This is not a matter which can be assessed in any way without a report by the committee. I determine that a motion in relation to the matter of alleged unauthorised disclosure may have precedence under standing order 81. I table the letter from Senators Abetz and Ferris. TALK.START.PARA: —I have some further information in response to a question from Senator Harradine on 22 October 1997 relating to Australia's response to the drought in Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Hill —Further to my answer to Senator Harradine's Question without Notice on 22 October 1997, on the drought in PNG and Irian Jaya I provide the following:

In relation to PNG, Mr Simon Kaumi, the Minister for Provincial and Local Government Affairs in Papua New Guinea called upon the international community and all donor agencies to contribute to the drought relief effort in Papua New Guinea on 23 October. Mr Kaumi said that drought relief was a matter of utmost urgency and called for immediate donor assistance.

A donors coordination meeting was held last week to discuss the outcomes of the "Report of an Assessment of the Impacts of Frost and Drought in PNG" completed by Australian experts last week. The meeting was convened by UNDP and attended by representatives from Australia, Japan, France, USA, New Zealand, European Union, and UNICEF and UNFPA.

The Report indicates that there is a serious threat of deterioration in the supply of staple food crops and water supplies in many areas. Approximately 100,000 people have been identified to be in critical situations, where there is very little food and water, and a high risk of people dying from starvation. A further 400,000 were identified to be in less critical situations, but likely to become critical in the near future if the expected November rains do not eventuate. The numbers within these categories could grow very quickly if effective action is not taken now. Some of the immediate concerns include dysentery outbreaks, the closing down of health clinics and the halt in processing of staple foods in some areas.
Donors welcomed the Report and will be working closely with the Government of PNG to provide appropriate assistance based on the findings of the Assessment Report.
UNDP has offered to continue to act as the coordination point for donors, who will continue to meet regularly.

As I said in my answer last week, Australian assistance is targeting those most in need. Australia has provided $3 million in assistance to date. Additional Australian RAAF aircraft have been provided to deliver supplies to the worst affected areas, which are inaccessible by road. A $1.2 million package of pharmaceuticals, including antibiotics, antimalarials anti-diarrhoea and rehydration preparations and syringes, is being provided to assist in alleviating health problems associated with the drought. An officer of Emergency Management Australia is continuing his work with the National Disaster Emergency Service (NDES) to help coordinate the relief exercise.
In relation to Irian Jaya, Australia is concerned about the long term effects of the drought in Irian Jaya (as well as other parts of eastern Indonesia).
Australia participated in an UN Disaster Assessment and Coordination mission to Irian Jaya from 3-8 October to assess the situation in Irian Jaya.
The main findings of the UN mission were that the prolonged dry season had pushed the local population to near its limits in terms of coping with food and water shortages.
The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has been holding discussions with the

Government of Indonesia authorities about the situation and the possibility of using a similar assessment methodology to that successfully employed in PNG. At this stage the Government of Indonesia is still considering our offers of assistance.

The Australian Government has committed a total of up to $2 million to assist Indonesia tackle the emergency problems resulting from the forest fires. Australian experts have been working in Indonesia assisting the Indonesian Government in fire management, health and medical assessments and aerial water bombing. Australian assistance has been coordinated with other major donors to the bushfire crisis, including Germany, Japan and the United Kingdom.
As a result of the forest fires haze problem the Government has offered to provide $300,000 to help Malaysia carry out an air quality study.
In addition to assistance to these countries, AusAID will respond to requests for emergency assistance in relation to the El Nino event on a case by case basis.

Let us not forget that Mr Beazley, as finance minister, oversaw this very spectacular Labor achievement. Let us get it on the record: it is Labor's fault that nursing homes are in crisis.

BREAK.PARA: Our aging population and increasing health care costs mean that the Australian government must take action to provide a much higher standard and a more acceptable level of accommodation and care for elderly Australians. Labor failed in this area. They shamefully ignored the issue of care for our aged and now they are trying to shift attention away from the mess and onto us.

Let us get some facts and some reality on the record. Income tested fees will begin on 1 March next year, but only for new residents. Residents who are in a nursing home or hostel now, or who enter care before 1 March, will not pay income tested fees. This protection will continue, even if they move to a different facility. If residents have paid higher fees in advance, any overpayment will be refunded. When income testing commences on 1 March for new residents only, their fees will not be affected by assets which they gave away before the aged care reforms were announced on 20 August. This will ensure that people who gifted assets before the reforms were announced will not face difficulties in paying their fees. Of course, hardship provisions will continue to be available for other residents who have genuine difficulty paying their fees.

Current hostel residents will now be protected from the increase in the hostel basic fee to bring it into line with the higher nursing home fees. This change, which took effect on 1 October, will now only affect residents entering hostels after that date. Current hostel residents who are paying the basic daily fee will have the same income left that they had on 30 September, as will hostel residents who are paying the higher variable fees.

Protection for the family home will be improved for accommodation bonds. The home itself will now be protected if a carer who is eligible for a pension or a benefit has lived there for the last two years, rather than for five years, as was previously the case. The family home will also continue to be automatically protected if a partner or dependent child lives there. For other family members, the five‐year provision will continue.

The reforms have always provided for residents who can pay a bond a number of alternatives to selling their homes—something that was well known by those opposite but was not used in its dirty political scare campaign. Residents can pay periodically or they can agree to take their accommodation contribution from their estate if they wish. The government has said it will listen to older people's concerns, and it has done so. The evidence is in the announcements made yesterday by the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) in the other place.

This package of changes will ease the transition to the new arrangements and provide additional protections for nursing home and hostel residents. We will continue to listen to suggestions for further options to allow more flexibility while maintaining the integrity of this policy. Unlike those opposite, we will not continue to ignore this sector of the community that was so disgracefully overlooked for 13 years by the Labor government.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

This bill proposes to amend the Quarantine Act 1908 and place in the hands of the minister responsible for the act the power to approve or deny applications from other nations to import products such as cooked chicken meat, salmon, apples and pears into Australia. This bill is about maximising the protection of our local product from disease. It seeks to do what was unanimously recommended by the all-party Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee and deserves the support of every member of this parliament.

Prior to the March 1996 election, the then shadow minister but now the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) gave the chicken industry, in particular, certain commitments in writing. However, since then he has attempted to walk away from these commitments, using his apparent lack of power under the act as an excuse. This bill, if supported, will give him that power. It will give him the opportunity to make good on his promises.
The bill is designed to provide our local industries with the greatest possible protection from diseases which currently do not exist in Australia.

I have heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and other government members suggest that this move will politicise the decision making process. We must meet our international obligations and commitments and have regard to scientific evaluation, but what is an acceptable risk? The Minister must determine what is an acceptable risk because it is the Minister that is accountable to the people through the parliament not departmental officials and other bureaucrats.
The consequences of a bad decision for our chicken, salmon and certain horticultural industries could be their total devastation.
The poultry industry is a $2 billion industry which employs tens of thousands of Australians directly and many more indirectly. It is a 100 per cent Australian-owned industry.

On the Central Coast, where I live, there is a large chicken industry involving 90 families and 1000 jobs. Newcastle Disease, the scourge of the poultry industry overseas, will wipe out this industry if it is accidentally introduced with chicken meat imports. It will not only wipe out the chicken industry on the Central Coast but it will wipe out our native bird population. Despite this, the Federal Government supports the applications from Thailand, Denmark and the United State to import cooked chicken into this country.

I notice that Members who have large chicken industries in their electorate such as the Member for Patterson and the Member for Robertson did not support this bill when it was presented in the House of Representatives by my colleague, the Member for the Hunter.

I hope that they have a good explanation for the 90 families and 1,000 people employed on the Central Coast, the 3,000 people in the Hunter region who are directly employed by the chicken processing and growing industries; for the many more people in the Hunter who are indirectly employed; for the more than 45,000 people Australia-wide who are employed either directly or indirectly by this industry; and, for the tens of thousands who are employed directly or indirectly by other industries such as the apple and pear industries and the salmon industry.

The all-party Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport unanimously supported the proposition that the final decision on these matters should rest squarely with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

The current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was appalled by the prospect that we might allow the importation of cooked chicken meat from countries such as Thailand, Denmark and the United States when he was a Shadow Minister in the then Opposition, and he told the industry so. In a letter to an industry representative dated 14 February 1996, he said this:

As you know, the federal coalition has for some time expressed concerns about the adequacy of Australia's quarantine arrangements and, in particular, the import risk assessment process used by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
He went on to say:
Our concerns have been confirmed by leading members of the scientific community.

Many scientific experts have said time and time again that allowing chickens to be imported into Australia involves enormous risk. We have now seen that Newcastle disease survives in Antarctic conditions, yet the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) want us to accept their proposition that somehow half cooking chicken meat can eradicate Newcastle disease.

AQIS were frustrated under the former Minister, Senator Bob Collins. They failed to gain his approval for the import of these products, so as soon as they had a new Minister in John Anderson they appealed again and this time they managed to get the Minister's support to allow cooked chicken meat to be imported. The Minister then claimed when confronted that he didn't have the power to change the decision even if he wanted to. This bill will give him the power and stop him from buck passing.

For the sake of the Australian poultry industry and the vital industry in regions such as the Central Coast, I ask Senators to support this bill. The risk from imported disease to Australia's chicken industry and native bird population is unacceptable.

What this bill does is put the power for decision on issues relating to quarantine in the hands of the Minister and ensures that the parliament is able to scrutinise his decision on behalf of the Australia people rather than leaving it in the hand of unaccountable bureaucrats.
I hope all Senators, particularly those that care about the viability of the chicken industry in Australia and our native wildlife threatened by imported diseases will support this bill.
