TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the gover nment's response to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee report on its review of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995, and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE COMMUNITY AFFAIRS LEGISLATION COMMITTEE REPORT (SEPTEMBER 1996) ON THEIR REVIEW OF THE HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT ACT 1995

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 3 —Medical Agreements and Clinical Freedom

The Committee recommends that contracts entered into between medical practitioners and health funds or hospitals at all times clearly uphold the professional duty of practitioners to treat patients according to their clinical needs.

The Committee believes that there are major differences between the health systems in the United States and Australia and that these difference would make the introduction of US‐style managed care arrangements unlikely. Nevertheless, the Committee believed that concerns about the impact of the Amendment Act in respect of clinical freedom to treat patients according to their clinical need should be addressed.

Legislative amendment should be introduced in the 1997 Spring session of Parliament which requires any contracts offered by funds or hospitals to contain an unambiguous undertaking to refrain from interfering in the clinical treatment of patients within the scope of accepted clinical practice.

The Committee recommends that the National Health Act 1953, be amended to provide for the public scrutiny of purchaser‐provider agreements by consumers, except for those parts of contracts dealing with the price arrangements entered into between the parties.

Concerns were raised by the Australian Association of Surgeons and the Complaints Commissioner over the lack of provision for public scrutiny of con tracts between doctors and funds. The Australian Health Insurance Association (AHIA) conceded that consumers are entitled to information in relation to any restrictions in contracts which might be alleged to impact on the quality of their health care delivery. However, AHIA argued that contracts should be entitled to commercial confidentiality insofar as price is concerned and other insurers have argued that conditions relating to payment times and terms should also be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence.

Legislation should be introduced in the Spring session of Parliament to provide for public scrutiny of purchaser‐provider agreements except for provisions dealing with price and other matters relating to payment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: B. RECOMMENDATION NOT SUPPORTED (BUT REQUIRING LEGISLATION)

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 13 —Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner

The Committee recommends that a re‐assessment of the functions, powers and funding arrangements of the Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner be part of the ongoing monitoring of the operation of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 to be undertaken by the Committee in accordance with Recommendation 1.

The Committee found that the Complaints Commissioner's Office has demonstrated that it provides a valuable contribution to the health industry and consumers. They acknowledge that there may be limitations in the powers and functions which affect the service provided to consumers, although this is yet to be demonstrated on such a limited period of operation. The Committee believes that more time needs to be given to assess the types and quantity of complaints and the effectiveness of their resolution before making any firm recommendation as to any possible expanded role and powers for the Complaints Commissioner.
The Committee's recommendation is not supported. Action is necessary now in some areas to ensure the efficient operation of the Complaints Commissioner. This will involve:
clarifying the financial management and accountability duties in relation to the holding and application of monies, and the entering into contractual agreements;
providing the Commissioner with the authority to delegate her powers; and
providing the Commissioner with the authority to require health funds and hospitals to provide information.

These measures, which will require legislative amendment, will assist the Commissioner to provide an effective and efficient operation over the next few years by which time information will be available to assess whether more substantial powers are required (such as the ability to impose sanctions for failure to act on a recommendation).
The Committee recommends that it continue to monitor the operation of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 and report to the Senate on or before 1 July 1998.
There would be some benefit in ongoing scrutiny of the legislation by an independent body, and the Senate Committee is well placed to undertake this task.
The continued monitoring of operation of the private health insurance legislation by the Senate Committee is supported.

The Committee recommends that the provisions relating to the implementation of Medical Purchaser‐Provider Agreements (MPPAs) under the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 proceed, subject to the recognition of the right of the medical profession to treat patients according to their clinical needs, the right of the profession to collectively negotiate contracts, subject to authorisation by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), and the right to public scrutiny of contracts as provided for in later recommendations.

The Committee recognises the Amendment Act provides an opportunity to address a major concern relating to out‐of pocket in‐hospital medical expenses. The Committee believes that the medical profession should co‐operate in negotiating contracts, but with the introduction of measures that address some of the concerns of the profession.
Supported—see recommendations 3 and 4.

The Committee recommends that groups of doctors or organisations representing the medical profession negotiate medical agreements with health funds or private hospitals by seeking authorisation of joint negotiations as provided for under the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The Committee believes that the professional independence of doctors will not necessarily be threatened by contracts and that as few contracts have been concluded to date, a proper assessment of whether contracts pose a threat to clinical freedoms cannot be made at this stage. The Committee believes that the authorisation provisions under the TPA already provide an appropriate mechanism for conducting joint negotiations.

The Government supports the right of medical practitioners the right to apply, where appropriate, to the ACCC for authorisation to enter collectively negotiated contracts with health funds. No legislation is required to provide the profession with the right collectively to negotiate contracts with funds and private hospitals, subject to the authorisation provisions of the Trade Practices Act. They already have access to these arrangements.

The Committee recommends that in the interests of continuing certainty in the contracting process, and recognising that contributors should not be totally disadvantaged, if in an emergency they are treated in a non‐contracted hospital, an appropriate default benefit should continue in place after 1 July 1997.

This recommendation is supported. While the Industry Commission supported the removal of the default benefit the Government's preferred position is to maintain a minimum default benefit and to review in two years' time.
The Committee recommends that private hospitals negotiate hospital agreements with health funds by seeking authorisation for joint negotiations as provided for under the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The Committee noted the concern that many country and/or smaller hospitals may have in negotiating contracts with funds and considered that contracting arrangements could be improved if smaller hospital groupings were able to collectively negotiate contracts with funds. The Committee also considered that the administrative costs involved in the negotiation process, especially for smaller hospitals, could be rationalised by permitting hospital groupings to collectively negotiate contracts with funds.

Although the Committee concludes that there is evidence of market dominance of the funds they did not recommend that the NHA be amended to allow private hospitals to form negotiation alliances (as proposed by the APHA). Rather, the Committee concluded that private hospitals should be encouraged to collectively negotiate by pursuing authorisation under the Trade Practices Act.

The Government supports the right of hospitals (both private and public) to apply, where appropriate, to the ACCC for authorisation to enter collectively negotiated contracts with health funds. No legislation is required to provide hospitals with the right collectively to negotiate contracts with funds subject to the authorisation provisions of the Trade Practices Act. They already have access to these arrangements.
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government take all available options to conclude the Relative Value Study of the MBS on an accelerated timetable.

The committee considered that the Amendment Act, through implementation of MPPAs, provides one approach to address the issue of eliminating out‐of‐pocket costs. However, the Committee suggests that the Commonwealth Government should consider other approaches to address the issue of medical gaps.

The Committee believes that any form of gap insurance needs to be limited in some sense. The AHIA, while favouring current arrangements, outlined an approach that involved allowing funds to pay medical benefits above the MBS, up to an amount determined by the fund. Payment of benefits above the MBS would be conditional on the fee not exceeding the published fund fee or the practitioner entering into an agreement with the fund in relation to a higher fee which, if it involved a co‐payment would be known to the contributor prior to consent to treatment.
The AMA argued that a factor in any solution must be the earliest possible production of an up to date fee schedule and argued that the Relative Value Study be concluded on an accelerated timetable.
The Relative Value Study should be concluded as soon as practicable, preferably within the next twelve months.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12—Aggregate Billing and Assigning of Medicare Benefits

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the proposal contained in the industry paper provided by the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and the Australian Private Hospitals Association (APHA), including the amendment of the Health Insurance Act 1973 to enable patients to assign benefits to third parties for private in‐patient episodes of care and the relaxation of restrictions on the payment of Medicare benefits, be the basis of further investigation and debate by the Aggregate Billing Advisory Committee. However, the consideration of reform by the Billing Committee should not be restricted only to the ideas in the AMA/APHA proposal

The AMA informed the Committee that the proposal outlined in "Aggregate Billing—Industry Position", had broad support from a group comprising private hospital and health insurer representatives, and medical representatives including the Council of Procedural Specialists (COPS) and the Australian Association of Surgeons (AAS). The basis of the proposal is to enable patients to assign benefits to a third party, with expertise in billing systems who can also receive and disburse payments.

The AHIA had a strong preference for maintaining the status quo (only patients treated by medical practitioners with contracts are able to assign the Medicare benefit in respect of in‐hospital medical services).

Consideration of the AMA/APHA paper on aggregate billing is supported. The Ministerial "round table" forum has considered the AMA/APHA industry paper in developing documentation related to the trialing of aggregate billing with informed financial consent. Expressions of interest to conduct trials have now been received and are being evaluated, and trials should be underway by early in 1997‐98.
Recommendation 14 —the Private Patients' Hospital Charter

The Committee recommends that the Private Patients' Hospital Charter be revised to include reference to the disclosure of patient information pursuant to section 73G of the National Health Act 1953 and ensure that the Charter does not contain information or advice which may be inconsistent with the provisions of section 73G.

The Committee considered that the Charter is an important component in the education of consumers about private health insurance and in particular as to their rights and expectation within the system.

The next reprint of the Private Patients' Hospital Charter will be redrafted to include appropriate reference to the provisions of section 73G of the National Health Act 1953 and other changes which may be necessary to cover legislative amendments arising from current Government deliberations in relation to private health insurance.

The Committee recommends that insurance funds, medical providers, hospitals and consumer‐oriented organisations accept greater responsibility in the production of information for consumers, the format of this information and in the availability and distribution of this consumer information.

Evidence to the Committee indicated that confusion and ignorance among consumers about private health insurance apparently remains widespread. Unfortunately, the major players in the industry attribute blame to each other and consider the problem to be the responsibility of others to rectify.

The Industry Commission did not consider that additional government measures over and above what is required in the legislation were necessary to provide information to consumers about particular health insurance products.
Supported—no Government action required.

The Committee recommends that documents such as the Private Patients' Hospital Charter and the PHIAC booklet "Insure? Not Sure?" be given a wider distribution and that it be a requirement to give these documents prominence when displayed in `shopfronts'.

The committee considered that "Insure? Not Sure?", was an informative and useful booklet for consumers but that it would have a greater impact by ensuring that when displayed it is clearly differentiated from insurance product advertising.

The Amendment Act requires as a condition of registration that funds make copies of the Charter available to contributors and members of the public, to place the Charter on display and to publicise the existence of the Charter in their brochures and other documents. The Complaints Commissioner and PHIAC are also required to make copies of the Charter available to members of the public on request and to publicise the existence of the Charter in any brochures or other documents.

PHIAC is required to collect and disseminate information about health insurance premiums and products. PHIAC's booklet "Insure, Not Sure" is a response to this requirement. PHIAC has distributed copies to the funds and members of the public on request. However, the funds are not formally required to make this information available.

The funds should be reminded via Departmental circular of their obligations in relation to the Charter. Updating "Insure, Not Sure" and requiring funds to make it available would be costly. PHIAC has recently made this publication available on the Internet and can now be easily down loaded by consumer groups and members of the public. Funds should be asked to inform their contributors of the availability of this information on the Internet.

The Committee recommends that these and other consumer information brochures be made available in languages other than English and that areas with large NESB communities be identified and targeted with the distribution of consumer information in the relevant language.

Recommendations 15, 16 and 17—Redrafting, translation into languages other than English and further promotion and distribution of the Private Patients' Hospital Charters will be considered following any changes in private health insurance that may occur as a result of Industry Commission inquiry and the Senate inquiry.

Decisions about amendments to the Charter will also need to be made in the light of available resources. The Private Health Sector Reform Program which provides the funds for the Charter's development and distribution will cease in June 1997.

The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the constitutional basis and feasibility of legislation to require informed financial consent for medical and hospital services, irrespective of whether or not a purchaser‐provider agreement exists.
There was support for strengthening informed financial consent from the industry as a whole.

The issue of informed financial consent has been dealt with by the Ministerial "round table". The proposed aggregate billing trials will be required to include a mechanism for informed financial consent. The need for legislative action will be clearer after the trials have been evaluated.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 20—Fund Information on the Complaints Commissioner

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that funds be required to include information relating to the Complaints Commissioner in their published material and to draw their customers' attention to the role and functions of the Complaints Commissioner.

This recommendation has already been met in a Conditions of Registration imposed on funds and promulgated in HBF Circular 463. Organizations currently have to include on a State by State basis details of all products or tables of benefits in a brochure. These brochures will now also have to include information relating to the Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner.
This information is to include:
. the fact that there is a Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner
. that people have a right to contact the Commissioner if they have a complaint regarding their health fund
. that the Commissioner is independent and that her services are free to members making a complaint
. contact details for both telephone and post

The Committee recommends that the Private Hospital Data Bureau be funded to operate on an interim basis until the end of 1998, and be operational from 1 January 1997. During this period consideration should be given to the Bureau's role, functions and funding base. The Bureau should aim to become self‐funding, though with tight security guidelines to ensure privacy breaches in the `selling' of data do not occur. A combination of industry funding, particularly by the private hospitals in an arrangement similar to that operating with the funds and the Complaints Commissioner, should be considered.

The Committee notes that consultations have been held with the private health sector to establish an interim bureau to collect data for two years. It was envisaged that during this interim period, further consultation and experience would assist in the drafting of relevant legislation for a self‐funding independent bureau.

The NHA requires that the role and responsibilities of the Data Bureau be defined after appropriate consultation with the private health sector. The initial two year operation of the bureau will be funded by the Department and conducted on a trial basis by a private tenderer under contract. The trial operation will be overseen by a steering committee drawn from members of the private health sector and other interested parties. During this time industry consultation will inform the drafting of legislation to establish a statutory body which will operate as an ongoing self funded Bureau.

A private contractor has been selected and negotiations over contractual arrangements are soon to be finalised. The Bureau will operate on a trial basis under Government contract for a two year period with a view to establishing a self funding bureau from then on.

The Committee recommends that a review of data collection at Federal and State levels be undertaken by the National Health Information Management Group (NHIMG) to ensure any duplication of effort and resources is prevented. This review should consider the role of the Private Hospital Data Bureau in the future collection and dissemination of data.

The duplication of data collection and the attendant costs were referred to in a number of submissions. Medibank Private (supported by similar recommendations from the Australasian Day Surgery Association) suggested that to gain efficiencies within the data collection process, NHIMG should review areas of duplication encompassing Commonwealth and State collections.

The need to standardise and simplify data flows in order to avoid duplication is recognised. It is for this reason that the HCP and Data Bureau data standards have been developed to be consistent with standards contained in the National Health Data Dictionary where possible. The consultation process for the Data Bureau has uncovered very diverse views on how best to simplify data collection processes. This issue will be addressed during the initial pilot phase of the Data Bureau

The recommendation is supported—with reservations about the use of the NHIMG. The Department will examine ways in which such a review might be conducted. While the NHIMG may provide a vehicle for resolving some aspects of this issue, there is no private sector representation on NHIMG. Consistent with other recommendations of the Report any review should not further delay the establishment of the Private Hospital Data Bureau.

The Committee recommends that the relevant privacy guidelines be revised to ensure that situations such as that which led to the disclosure of private patient information do not recur and that the use of data collected under the HCP is appropriately covered by such guidelines.

The Committee notes that amendments in the Amendment Act require that hospitals and day hospital facilities transfer the information specified in the Hospital Casemix Protocol to their contracted health funds. The importance of accurate and timely data has been emphasised by funds. The provision of more data assists all concerned with policy formulation, including legislators.

The Report notes that: "to ensure that data exchange is effective, it is essential that all parties have complete confidence that the information they provided in relation to the operation of the legislation is treated with absolute respect and security.

This conclusion is supported. The Department does not receive patient identified data as part of the HCP collection and if patient identified data was mistakenly submitted there is no facility to store such data in the HCP collection. Procedures will be established to ensure that data and reports distributed by the HCP collection remain de‐identified.
The Committee recommends that the Purchaser‐Provider panel be convened and that the sunset clause which limits the life of the Panel to 30 June 1997 be deleted.
The Committee believes that the Purchaser‐Provider Panel should be established as provided for in the Amendment Act.
Not supported. The industry does not support the establishment of the Panel.

The Committee recommends that the Purchaser‐Provider Panel be provided with access to purchaser‐provider agreements as part of its monitoring role relating to contractual arrangements entered into between the relevant parties.

The Committee believes that the Purchaser‐Provider Panel should be provided with access to purchaser‐provider agreements to enhance its role in monitoring the legislative provisions relating to contracts and provide a consumer focus to the oversight of contracts.
Not supported. There is no support in the industry for the Panel to have a role in monitoring contracts.
The Committee recommends that the Aggregate Billing Advisory Committee be convened as provided for in the Amendment Act.
The Committee strongly supports the necessity for urgent reform of the billing system.

One of the outcomes of the Committee's report was the establishment of a Ministerial "round table" consisting of industry leaders and consumer representatives. This group was able to make considerable headway on ways to progress simplified billing and informed financial consent. Trials are expected to proceed in the near future.

The recommendation is not supported. The Ministerial "round table" forum has obviated the need for a formal Aggregate Billing Advisory Committee. Aggregate billing is also dealt with by the Industry Commission.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 18—PHIAC and Comparative Data on Products

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that PHIAC should, as part of its statutory function of collecting and disseminating information, publish comparative (including cost) of major insurance products on a regular basis.

The Committee noted that the dilemma with product choice lies in the balance between funds being able to offer a greater range of products to consumers, and the need to ensure that a larger diversity of available product does not simply create greater confusion for the consumer.

The Committee's recommendation is not supported. It would be extremely difficult for anyone to provide a meaningful comparison between products. This is because there are so many products and the products are so diverse. The Industry Commission also considered this issue and concluded that it doubted whether government involvement in direct product and price comparisons could be justified.

The Committee recommends that the disclosure of data under section 73G of the National Health Act 1953 be the subject of community and industry consultation and debate as to what are acceptable secondary uses for personal health information and what are appropriate safeguards to be applied in using such information at this wider level.

The Privacy Commissioner referred to the provisions of section 73G of the NHA, inserted by the Amendment Act ostensibly to remove any impediment under law which would prevent the disclosure of information by hospitals relating to the provision of hospital treatment. The Privacy Commissioner believes that this section raises privacy concerns as it appears to widen the range of people and organi sations who may have access to personal health information.

The Government does not agree that provision of data necessary for assessing and making private health insurance benefit payments is a secondary use of personal health information. Registered Health Benefits Organisations have always received billing data in a patient identifiable state, as this data is needed for verifying and paying claims. The HCP collection does not change this. As mentioned above, the Department will not receive patient identified data as part of the HCP collection and procedures will be established to ensure that data and reports distributed remain de‐identified.

The Government agrees that a community and industry debate on acceptable uses for personal health information should be conducted. It should include all health management information systems using such data. This would include hospital, private doctor, state health authority, and health fund uses of these data.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the annual report of the Joint House Department for the year ended 30 June 1997.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make just a few brief comments in relation to the legislation which is the subject of the committee's report. When this inquiry began, a very, very wide gulf existed in terms of wheat marketing—particularly with the export market—between the eastern and western sides of the country. The point I would make here is that, during the process of the bringing together of the committee's report, most issues have been resolved and are no longer outstanding. However, there are a couple of issues that I would like to touch on briefly.

BREAK.PARA: The first issue relates to the situation that exists with taxation, where there is an outstanding issue as far as the industry and some of the people in it are concerned. At this point I should also mention the fact that, being a partner in a wheat growing operation, I have an interest in the industry and in the outstanding issues of how taxation is to be treated, particularly relating to capital gains tax, with the conversion of funds from WIF into shares, as the matter progresses.

Another issue raised was that of the first and second tranches of the legislation. In this report the preferred position of the opposition was to delay this legislation and get the whole matter dealt with in one piece of legislation. There is a point that I want to make relating to that—and it is certainly not the position of the committee nor the government: this legislation, as is pointed out in the report, can stand alone in its own right. Nonetheless, I believe that over the early part of next year we will see the second tranche of the legislation come before us. It will finalise the position where growers in the industry, through the corporatised Australian Wheat Board with its separate structures of A and B class shares, will take control of and own the industry.

These issues were technically outside the committee's terms of reference. Nonetheless, the industry representatives—whether from the Grains Council or the various states, New South Wales and Western Australia in particular—did raise all the various issues and matters.

I will have more to say on these matters as and when the bill comes before the Senate. However, I would make the point that it is very important, we believe, to allow this legislation to go forward at this time, so that the Wheat Board can set up its new modernised structures, get its lines of credit in place and do the necessary things to move the marketing of wheat into the next century. After 1999, the privatisation of the wheat industry will come to fruition, and this piece of legislation is an interim step along that road.

I commend this report to the Senate. This piece of legislation, being enabling legislation, will allow that progression to the modernisation of the wheat industry. Funds will have been compulsorily acquired from growers for 10 years at a rate of two per cent per annum. At the end of that time, the growers, through the issuing of a prospectus in due course, will be able to get access to their funds.

In some instances, particularly once again in the state I come from, Western Australia, there are some very large contributions to that particular fund running out to $250,000. So it becomes very important to growers to be able to access that capital base, as well as through the A and B class share arrangements and the corporate structure that has been put in place, and to be able to keep control of the industry.

There is a lot more relevant detail and, as I said, we will go into it in the debate on the bill. But I make these points at this time. I commend this legislation to the Senate, and I wish it a speedy passage through this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators, I commend the various organisations that made submissions to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee in relation to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997. Also, I commend the committee secretariat for their assistance in the drafting of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Our position, which is in opposition to some of the matters to which Senator Crane has referred, is contained in the report proper, and no dissenting or minority report has been published. I would draw the attention of the Senate to those parts of the report which set out our dissent in relation to the report.

It should be said that we support the general principle of the legislative scheme proposed, at least in part, by this bill—and that is, we support an overall package of measures to achieve the stated end aim. However, we do not agree that it is appropriate to process this scheme through a two-stage legislative arrangement. We are dealing with one tranche of the legislation now. We will see the second tranche of legislation some time in the New Year perhaps, dependent upon the processes of government. Those two tranches together form the legislative scheme that we give our support to.

It can only be in the government's mind at this stage what exactly will be in the second tranche of legislation. We believe that if as legislators we are to support a package, we should have that package before us. We enumerate some of those concerns in the report summary at the bottom of page 2, going to page 3. We say there:

While there has been essentially bi‐partisan support for the legislation scheme proposed by the Bill, differences between the members of the Committee have arisen over the timing of its consideration by the Senate.

There was concern expressed by a number of industry representatives that they were being asked to endorse the whole wheat legislation package without having the opportunity to scrutinise all the detail of that package.
The industry is also concerned that it is being asked to endorse the new structure for the AWB without knowing the details of the new taxation regime to apply.

You will see in the report that there is quite a deal of material about concerns particularly about taxation arrangements that apply to the wheat industry fund moneys as they are converted to category B shares under the proposed incorporated arrangements of the new Australian Wheat Board.

In terms of the formal opposition recommendation, I suppose it can be encapsulated in the statement which appears, I think, on page 3 of the printed report. I do not have a copy before me, but that is my understanding of where it appears. It says:

BREAK.PARA: The Opposition Members of the Committee recommend that consideration of the Bill be deferred until the industry, and this Committee, examine the details of the whole package of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 10th report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , together with submissions and transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is the first step towards restoring certainty for all Australians involved in native title claims. The committee's report concluded that it is a fair and sensible response to the problems which have become evident both in the operation of the act and in response to the High Court's Wik decision.

The committee received a wide range of evidence from a large number of groups and individuals in the pastoral and resources industries, Aboriginal and indigenous communities and wider community groups which clearly demonstrated the unworkability of the existing Native Title Act. In fact, it was described by the Australian Mining and Exploration Council as both `ineffective and unworkable'. In particular, AMEC described the current right to negotiate regime as an effective statutory infrastructure cost which mining companies now need to build in as an additional cost for virtually any new project they are interested in developing.

Other evidence was given of the investment which is being driven overseas because of native title concerns. Ms Catherine Hobbs, a geologist and consultant to a medium sized mining and exploration company, told the committee of her extensive experience in Western Australia and in South Australia, particularly with the right to negotiate process prescribed by the Native Title Act. Her experiences were particularly valuable as they were derived from people working at the coalface of native title negotiations with indigenous groups as well as herself having worked in the mining industry for more than 25 years. She told the committee:
We now have a situation where it is common for competing overlapping claims to be lodged by sisters and brothers, and even for the same people—
that is, we can have two or more native title claims over the same area, by the same signatories—

Some native title claimants also express anger and frustration that they cannot access the benefits they seek from the mining industry, because of unachievable, high demands made by competing claimants which they consider to be without any foundation.

There is very clear evidence for the need for amendment. That is the all too often tragic refrain that we heard when we visited remote communities, Alice Springs, Cairns and Broome. Native title disputes have the capacity to divide communities, to set Aboriginal group against Aboriginal group, family against family, brother against sister—to say nothing of the divisive situation in many remote regional towns in this country where Aborigines were previously an accepted part of the wider community and indeed were respected members of the community. When genuine efforts of mining companies to reach agreements with indigenous people are frustrated by tribal jealousies and rivalries, not only do the mining companies lose out but it clearly works against the financial benefit of the indigenous parties.

It is very disturbing to see the evidence of the overlapping claims in this country. In this place just last week I spoke of the very sad experiences of a remote pastoral family who tried very hard three years ago to establish an agreement for access that a claimant group wanted to their property but have been frustrated to the extent that they now find themselves in the Federal Court and with the likely cost of millions of dollars.

This is the tragedy of the Native Title Act as it stands now. It serves to create anger, frustration and division on all sides and patently does nothing for reconciliation. The Native Title Amendment Bill tries to address some of these concerns in a balanced, fair and I believe sensible way. I commend the committee's report to the Senate for its consideration.

Madam President, the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board brings to fruition a process dating back to 1989 aimed at putting ownership and control of wheat marketing firmly in growers' hands. This will enable industry to control its own future without the restrictions of Government control and regulation.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is pleased to acknowledge that the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board has been driven by the grains industry.

The push for change started in 1989, when industry commenced building up funds for a capital base for a future grower owned Australian Wheat Board via a levy on wheat sales, paid into the Wheat Industry Fund.

In 1991 at the Grains 2000 conference, industry, through the Grains Council of Australia, recognised that the Australian Wheat Board needed greater flexibility to be best able to respond to changes in international marketing in order to compete successfully and maximise returns to growers. Further, the industry acknowledged that a marketing structure which is fully commercially driven is best achieved if it is owned and controlled by industry rather than by Government.

In 1992, the wheat industry entered into a compact with the then Government for change. Specifically, the industry agreed that Government underwriting of Australian Wheat Board borrowings should cease in 1999 and for the Wheat Industry Fund to continue to be built up over that period towards a target figure of $500‐550 million.

It was decided that $500‐550 million would provide sufficient backing for the Australian Wheat Board to borrow the funds it requires to make harvest payments to growers without a Government guarantee. It would also fund other Australian Wheat Board activities such as domestic grain trading and value adding activities in grain storage and processing overseas.

At Grains Week in April 1996, industry and Government agreed that wheat marketing arrangements post 1999 should be based on the objectives of grower ownership and control, self reliance and a fully commercial approach to marketing. At that same time, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy asked industry to develop a plan which would ensure that this goal would be met.

To assist in this, a Grains Council of Australia/Australian Wheat Board/Department of Primary Industries and Energy Working Group was formed to facilitate industry consideration of possible restructuring. The membership of the group included representatives from all Grains Council of Australia State affiliate organisations so that growers would have the opportunity to put forward their views.

Further, to provide stability throughout the restructuring process, the Government reiterated its commitment to retain the export monopoly and for the National Competition Policy Review to be delayed until 1999/2000.

After much consultation and deliberation, in March 1997 the Working Group put to Government an agreed framework for a new structure. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is pleased that the Government has readily been able to accept this framework, which he announced at Grains Week in April 1997.

From 1 July 1999, wheat marketing will be undertaken not by the current statutory Australian Wheat Board but by a grower owned and controlled company operating under Corporations Law. The company will assume responsibility for all commercial aspects of wheat marketing, including financing and operation of wheat pools.
The new organisation will comprise a holding company with two subsidiaries: a pooling subsidiary and a domestic trading subsidiary.

Shares in the holding company will be issued in two classes: one A‐class share will be issued to each grower and the Wheat Industry Fund will be converted to B‐class shares. B‐class shares will be issued to Wheat Industry Fund equity holders on the basis of one share for every unit in the Wheat Industry Fund and will provide the company's capital base.

A‐class shares will be issued only to wheat growers. They will be non‐transferable and redeemed as holders leave the industry or fail to qualify as a wheat grower. A‐class shares will confer voting rights to elect the majority of directors of the holding company, and hence control of the holding company. They will not attract dividends or other returns.
As the providers of equity, B‐class shareholders will have the right to elect a minority of directors and will receive a commercial rate of return.
To achieve this structure by 1 July 1999, the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board will require legislative change in two stages, now and in 1998. This bill represents stage one.

Madam President, before outlining in detail the key elements of the bill, so that there can be no doubt, let me make clear that the amendments contained in this bill in no way threaten the security of the export monopoly—it will continue to be enshrined in the legislation. The export monopoly is a fundamental part of both National Party policy and Coalition policy.

Until 30 June 1999, responsibility for the export monopoly will rest with the Australian Wheat Board. Thereafter, the export monopoly will continue to be provided for in legislation. An independent regulatory mechanism will also be established to manage and monitor the performance of the export monopoly.
Madam President, turning now to the bill itself, it addresses the following key areas:
. the transitional provisions to apply until 30 June 1999;
. the cessation of the Wheat Industry Fund levy in 1999; and
. the composition of the board of the Australian Wheat Board.
Transitional Provisions to Apply Until 30 June 1999

In broad terms, the transitional provisions of the bill provide for the redistribution of current Australian Wheat Board functions between the Australian Wheat Board, a new holding company, and two subsidiaries, a pooling and domestic trading subsidiary. In the bill, the companies are referred to as Company `A', Company `B' and Company `C' respectively.

The holding company will be a wholly owned subsidiary of the Australian Wheat Board. It will be this company which in 1999 will become the grower owned and controlled company, with a capital base provided by the Wheat Industry Fund, distributed as shares to growers.

The purpose of the new company structure is to allow the holding company, as the future grower owned company, to develop an operational and financial track record over the next two years. It will be able to develop its own identity in international capital markets so that it can be competitive in the marketplace for borrowing in its own right for its activities from 1 July 1999.
The structure also addresses a key concern of growers by providing for a distinct separation of wheat pooling activities from other trading activities.

The objective is for the holding company and its associated subsidiaries to be operational as soon as possible to allow the future grower owned company the maximum amount of time possible to develop a track record. The memorandum and articles of association for the companies for the period to 1999 have been agreed with industry.

From the commencement of these arrangements, the operating functions of the Australian Wheat Board will be reduced. In essence, the primary functions of the Australian Wheat Board will be management of the export monopoly; management of the Wheat Industry Fund; and overseeing the activities of its subsidiary, the holding company. The Australian Wheat Board will be accountable to both industry and Parliament for performance of these functions.

Madam President, the holding company will be a commercial company operating under Corporations Law. It will assume the overarching responsibility for the pooling and commercial operations of the current Australian Wheat Board, including trade in wheat and grain and value adding activities.

The pooling operations will be carried out by Company B. The bill provides for the holding company to undertake borrowings, on behalf of its pools subsidiary, for the purpose of pool related payments, with such borrowings to be guaranteed by the Commonwealth until 1999.
The holding company will also establish a domestic trading subsidiary, Company C, to carry out the grain trading functions currently undertaken by the Australian Wheat Board.

Madam President, to ensure that the Wheat Industry Fund reaches its target of $550m in 1999 and provides a sound capital base for the new company, the tax provisions of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 will continue to apply. Specifically, the operations of the Australian Wheat Board, the Wheat Industry Fund and the pooling subsidiary will continue to be free from income tax until 30 June 1999. However, consistent with the Government's Competitive Neutrality policy, normal income tax arrangements will apply to non‐pooling activities.
Cessation of the Wheat Industry Fund Levy
The bill provides for the cessation of the Wheat Industry Fund component of the levy on 30 June 1999.

The Wheat Industry Fund now stands at around $430m and there is a possibility it could exceed $550m in mid 1999 if current strong prices and production levels continue. The financial consultants advise that the Wheat Industry Fund of $550m would allow the new company to fund the current range and level of services provided by the Australian Wheat Board.

The second phase of legislative change, to be introduced in 1998, will provide that on 1 July 1999, ten years after the commencement of the Wheat Industry Fund, equity in the Fund will be transferred to growers, the rightful owners, in the form of B class shares in the holding company.
Composition of the Board of the Australian Wheat Board

The bill provides for amendment to various sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 relating to the board of the Australian Wheat Board. Specifically, current members will continue to serve on the board until November 1998 when their present term of appointment expires.

Thereafter, the bill provides for the appointment of not more than eleven members to the board. In light of the reduced functions of the Australian Wheat Board from the commencement of these arrangements and to provide maximum flexibility in the appointments process in November 1998, the bill does not specify the actual size of the board, only a maximum.

Further, given that there will be only a seven month period during which new members will need to be appointed, a selection committee process will not be required. The rationale behind this is simply to minimise the costs, ultimately borne by growers, associated with appointments.
However, in making appointments to the board, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy must consult with industry, through the President of the Grains Council of Australia.
In keeping with the current legislation, the Minister must also ensure that among the members there is a balance of skills in the areas of production, marketing and finance.
Conclusion

Madam President, the final step towards a Corporations Law company under grower ownership and control will be taken in 1998 by way of a second package of legislation. The primary focus of the legislation will be the transfer of the Wheat Industry Fund into growers' hands, its rightful owners. It will also provide for the stripping away of all the commercial provisions for wheat marketing which will not be needed after an independent, grower owned company assumes these functions in 1999.

Thereafter, the restrictive, paternalistic role of Government will cease and the destiny of the industry will be placed firmly in growers' hands. From 1 July 1999, the industry will stand on its own two feet. The only Government involvement will be in relation to the export monopoly.

The amendments contained in this bill, and those to be introduced next year, finalise the restructure of wheat marketing and will stand industry in good stead for the future as an internationally competitive industry which continues to make a significant contribution to the Australian and rural economies.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition may, at any time before the caretaker period for a general election, seek the assistance of the responsible Secretaries to advise and to cost policy options provided that:

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal is for a new clause that will seek to equalise the opportunity afforded to both the government and the opposition when it comes to the analysis of the cost implications of each party's proposed policies. What this proposal essentially seeks to do is give the opposition at any time prior to the caretaker period the same opportunity enjoyed by the government to develop policy options in a manner that both is responsible and has regard to the public interest when it comes to the costing of policies.

It allows the Leader of the Opposition to seek the assistance of the responsible secretaries to advise on and cost policy options provided: first, the responsible secretaries have the discretion to decline any request where it would impose an unreasonable workload on the department; second, the request by the leader may relate to costings and revenue estimates and may include policy advice; third, the leader may at any time withdraw a request that has been made by notice in writing to the secretary; and, fourth, any request made by the leader may not be disclosed by the secretary to any person unless authorised to do so by the leader.

Given the importance the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has personally attached to an open and transparent policy costing process it is imperative that, for this new proposed regime to have any credibility, both the opposition and the government be on an equal footing in this process. If the policy costing process is to be done on an unequal footing, essentially on terms laid down by the government, the quality of public debate to flow from the process will be diminished and become overtly politicised, which I would have thought the government would be seeking to avoid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill, which allows me to make a few remarks on native title. I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate an article by Asa Wahlquist which ran in last weekend's Weekend Australian . It was entitled `Cultivating fear' and was clearly written with the intention of undermining the NFF President, Don McGauchie.

SPEECH.PARA: This feature contained many errors and misrepresentations about the role of the NFF and its president in the native title debate. The basic premise of the article was that a growing number of rural groups were breaking with the NFF leadership over the issue of native title. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Neither Rick Farley, John Purcell or Robert Hadler, all quoted in the article to support this view, currently hold any elected position with a major rural group. They are no longer active players in rural politics and they do not have a brief from farmers. On the other hand, Don McGauchie has been re‐elected for a fourth term as NFF president. This would not have happened had he not enjoyed considerable confidence from the rural community. Asa Wahlquist described his re‐election as extraordinary. That is to insult NFF voters and only goes to prove that the basic premise of the article is without foundation.

Mr Farley, on the other hand, is very much out of favour in the bush. It is quite wrong to put him up as an expert on rural opinion, yet it is obvious that Farley is the major source of this article. Rick Farley is developing into a spoiler in the interests which he once tried to represent. There is nothing new in his position to warrant the excited introduction which claimed that a growing number of rural groups are breaking ranks. Mr Farley is not a rural group but a native title negotiator whose views are already well‐known.

The strategy is clear: try to discredit a chief spokesman on the opposite side, in order to win the debate. Go for the eyes and try to hit the pivot, in the hope of crippling your opposition. In this case, if you take McGauchie out, you leave the farmers without their strongest voice on native title. That is the object of this article. That is the reason behind the choice of the article.

A former rural group office holder, Mr John Purcell, is also quoted. Mr Purcell will find it difficult to live down the role he played in the Cape York agreement because it has caused so much bad feeling among pastoralists, both black and white, on the cape and has failed to move forward. Strangely, Mr Purcell seems to have changed his tune on extinguishment since he voted in favour of the NFF's policy at a meeting in January 1997. It should also be noted that the NFF has nothing against voluntary agreements for traditional access. This has long been its policy.

It is clear that the article is designed to undermine the farmers' champion on the native title issue, and it does so in a very one‐sided way. Unlike the days under Rick Farley's mantle, when there was considerable unrest in the membership ranks over the NFF's direction and closeness with the Labor administration, the NFF has widespread support for its stance on native title. The article in fact mentioned by name the many supporters of the NFF such as the United Graziers Association in Queensland, the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association and the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia.

These groups represent many thousands of those directly affected by native title legislation. These are the major stakeholders in the native title debate in the farming community. Yet the author failed to provide any comment from these organisations to balance the feature. Only disparaging comments were quoted at length, and those who made them do not even represent any rural group. The feature reported:
There are 28 State farming and commodity groups in the NFF, representing 115,000 farmers.

Yet the author could not find one current representative of any of these bodies to support her hypothesis that rural groups were breaking ranks with the NFF. There was no backup to this beat‐up. The only critics the author could find were three former representatives, each now with there own axe to grind, and a mining representative—not a farmer.

It should be very obvious that mining companies are in a totally different position to family farmers when it comes to negotiating and to legal and financial resources. There is no comparison. In addition, large mining companies can simply walk away if negotiations fail to come up with a commercially viable solution. That is not so with farming families and grazing families. Where can they go? They cannot walk off and start up overseas instead, as mining companies can.

The feature was entitled `Cultivating fear'. It was the Wik decision alone which created the fear, the anxiety and the depression felt by so many in the bush. Rural families once trusted Rick Farley to deliver them certainty of tenure and title. Who can blame them now for being sceptical about the ramifications of forced coexistence in a land ownership regime which recognises two different types of title on one property?

McGauchie is right to be strong on this issue—here we are so far into the debate and still no‐one knows what native title means. So much hinges on this. How could the leader of Australian farmers sign off on a deal when there are still so many crucial unknowns that will affect his constituents—so many court cases yet to come, so much money yet to be spent; time and worry.

The author of the feature presents the argument that all farmers are being branded rednecks for the sake of only a few thousand pastoral leases. How principled a leader would McGauchie be if he were to treat one section of the constituency different from the others?

It is no wonder that there is fear. In one of the most recent native title claims in areas of the Sunshine Coast north of Brisbane, the Undanbi people continue to use the language of claiming exclusive possession, with ongoing rights to occupation, use and enjoyment, and of determining the future of the land, water and resources to the exclusion of all others. Point (f) of their application claims a right to live on and erect residences and other infrastructure on the land.

The Meat Industry Council is nearing the end of its statutory term and is winding down its operations as the industry prepares for the implementation of the new red meat board, which the government has put legislation forward to set up. During the transition period, the Meat Industry Council will maintain a monitoring role in a number of programs while overseeing the handover. It will certainly keep an eye on the meat industry strategic plan, which it has been instrumental in fostering.

It goes without saying that the beef industry is one of Australia's most important agricultural industries. Over recent years it has contributed between 11 and 19 per cent of the gross value of agricultural production, and that is about $3 billion worth of export income.

Along with wool, the beef industry is Australia's most dispersed agricultural industry, reaching from the far north of north‐western Western Australia to the hobby farmers in the south, and it is an industry that has played an enormous role in regional Australia and has developed much of our hinterland.

Its impact is very important to all those people who are employed in trucking and other areas of the transport industry, as well as in the production of feed, feedlotting, grain production and the abattoirs. A whole range of related employment in country towns depends substantially on the beef industry. Its prosperity is essential because over the last 25 years the industry has faced many challenges that have substantially altered the focus of production and the financial performance of the individual producers.

Much of the industry has come under major financial, economic and market pressures, and that has been especially so over the last few years. These pressures have not all been the responsibility of government. They have often been the result of drought, falling cattleyard prices in response to increased production in the United States, increasing competition in our export markets and, of course, recent food safety scares worldwide which have impacted on the amount of red meat that is being consumed. Inefficiencies on our waterfront and in our abattoirs have had a very detrimental effect on our export performance, and the cost price squeeze over recent years has affected all primary producers and not just beef producers. There has also been a corruption of world markets and a lack of access to markets, especially European markets and, at certain times, markets in North America. An overall trend has been a lack of growth in our own domestic markets.

The government has recently announced the new meat industry board which will be a producer‐owned body with responsibility for the sheep and beef industries, including promotion, research and development of both those red meats.The Meat Industry Council will no longer exist and, as such, we move forward. This is probably not the last annual report, as there will be another one for this financial year, but I note the important role the Meat Industry Council has played. But the baton is shortly to be passed to a grower‐controlled board. With that change we can look forward to a more efficient meat industry and, with good seasons and an expanding international market, I think the prospects are improving all the time.

The annual report of the CSIRO sets out a range of significant achievements for the year. Obviously, I am sure that we would all want to congratulate the CSIRO on another year of excellent results, especially at a time of fiscal restraint by this government—not to mention short-sightedness—in relation to the role of science and technology in our future. In fact, the small amount of time available to me tonight is not enough to focus on the range of achievements set out in this report. So I will just focus on what is a significant sector that the government should not overlook in its myopic funding decision making.

The Australian Democrats acknowledge the special need to save Australia's wildlife as being a key issue for Australian science as well as for our economic wellbeing in the future. Similarly, the CSIRO is committed to this goal, and the annual report sets out some of its achievements in reaching that particular objective.

The magnitude of the threat to Australian wildlife is total. The issue cannot be overstated. The threat is to individual species, whole ecosystems, and the potential of the planet to support life as we know it. The worldwide estimates of extinction rates for species as a proportion of the total number of estimated species ranges from one to 11 per cent per decade; that is, about 100,000 species per year, or about another 20,000 species by the end of this year, will become extinct. This is pretty scary stuff. But what is perhaps a little sadder is that we have no record of many of these extinctions. They are gone forever, and their unique solution to biology's problems tend to be lost without trace.

The problem for Australia is particularly severe. Australia is mega diverse, with high levels of endemic species. Already a large number of these species have been lost. In the last 200 years, some one in five mammals have become, or are at risk of becoming, extinct. Similar risks apply to higher flora for insects and the world of prokaryotes. The situation is pretty severe.

The government's drive to cut education and research funding threatens the identification and preservation of Australia's unique wildlife. This is strongly acknowledged within the CSIRO. But, through science and appropriate technology, Australia could save this world heritage and genetic diversity. The CSIRO is central to this particular task, and I have to say that its record is particularly impressive.

There are direct and indirect benefits from preserving biodiversity. They range from crop yields to air and water quality. Unfortunately, conservation biology and the long‐term crisis of environmental overload does not seem to enter the present economic debate. In fact, the failure of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) even to mention science in last year's budget, I think, is an indictment of the government's understanding when it comes to the value of biological resources.

Australia's vanishing wildlife must be saved by moves to recognise the crisis and take measures to halt the tragic loss. This is a message that the CSIRO is forever trying to get out, and many of our politicians—senators in this place and members in the lower House—attend regular CSIRO briefing seminars at which the importance of the role of science in the community as well as the need to save our natural heritage are explained.

A summary of that can be found in the comments of then Senator Sid Spindler on 15 December 1993, where he said:
The High Court's Mabo judgment deals with the proof required to establish native title. The report from the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs states:

Proof of the existence of native title is relatively difficult to establish. The elements include the need to show the existence of an identifiable community or group; that there be a traditional connection with the land under the laws and customs of the Aboriginal group; and that there has been a substantial maintenance of the connection since Crown sovereignty. These elements will place strict limits upon the making of successful claims to native title.
The then Senator Sid Spindler went on to say:

In recognition of this difficulty, and the fact that over most usable land in Australia native title has been extinguished, this bill contains a provision for the establishment of a land acquisition fund . . .

So that is in fact the genesis of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Honourable senators may recall a previous speech I gave on the indigenous land fund and my concern that, in the whole topic of native title in this country and the submissions made by the national indigenous working group overseas in the context of native title, the indigenous land fund in fact was not mentioned. When I say `not mentioned', I mean that the extent of it is not mentioned.

It should be recalled by all Australians that what has been set up with the Indigenous Land Corporation is in fact a perpetual fund which, as of 1 July 1997, allows $45 million indexed to be drawn down for the Indigenous Land Corporation each and every year. The allocation to the fund at the end of 2004 will be $1.289 billion. Retained in the land fund at the end of that period will be $859 million.

It is important to note that the contributions by the Australian taxpayers have been made in full and on time as per the requirement of the legislation. It is also good to see that the Indigenous Land Corporation has in fact been moving to undertake land purchases and the board has given approval to proceed to purchase a total of 45 properties, which, just by way of interest, include a range of properties from pastoral leaseholds to freehold title.

The corporation I think give a full and detailed account of the way that they are administering their moneys. They raise one concern in their report at page 19 and then develop it further on pages 38 and 39, and that is the difficulty in Queensland of their being unable to buy grazing homestead freehold leases and grazing homestead perpetual leases because the Queensland legislation requires that those types of leases be held by individuals and operated in effect as family farms. Such leases may not be transferred to corporate ownership, and that of course includes the Indigenous Land Corporation. Therefore, we have the situation where the Indigenous Land Corporation, because of their structure, are unable to buy some of these leases in the state of Queensland.

I conclude my remarks this evening by simply urging the Queensland government to give consideration as to whether the regime can be altered to in fact allow the Indigenous Land Corporation to make such purchases for the benefit of the indigenous community within this country.
