DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Crime and Punishment in the Northern Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about crime and punishment in the Northern Territory. I am referring to the Country Liberal Party government's mandatory sentencing provisions for property offences, which have totally skewed the scales of justice in the Territory. They came into effect on 8 March this year through amendments to the Sentencing Act and the Juvenile Justice Act. The amendments contain a schedule of offences, including car theft, criminal damage, breaking and entering and stealing, that result in compulsory imprisonment for convicted adult and juvenile offenders.

SPEECH.PARA: For adults, it is one strike and you are in. I might add that an adult is someone 17 years and 28 days old. A first offence is met with an automatic 14 days imprisonment and it is 90 days gaol for a second offence and a minimum of a 12‐month prison term for repeat offences.

For juveniles, it is two strikes and you are in. A magistrate must impose a period of at least 28 days detention on a juvenile, defined as anyone who is 15 or 16 years of age, who has been found guilty of one of the prescribed property offences and has at least one prior conviction for a similar offence.

These mandatory sentencing laws enjoy the support of the majority of territorians. I am not among them. It is my earnest hope that a number of recent well‐publicised cases will force among territorians a major rethink about these laws.

One has recently changed his view. His name is Ray McCosker. He is a law‐abiding father of five. Mr McCosker was recently charged with criminal damage after admitting to police he cut a piece of steel off a chook shed which a neighbour had built onto his fence. He lived for months with the prospect of leaving his wife and five children at the front door of Darwin's Berrimah Prison until the charges against him were dropped on the grounds of insufficient evidence on the day he appeared in court.

Others have not been so fortunate. Take the case of 23-year-old single mother Margaret Wynbyne. Margaret pleaded guilty to stealing a single can of beer, valued at $2.50, and unlawful entry at the Wanda Inn at Top Springs on 13 March this year. It was her first offence. Margaret, who was employed in a women's shelter at Kalkaringi, was sentenced to 14 days in prison.

The matter is currently under appeal before a full bench of the Northern Territory Supreme Court. Her lawyers are arguing, as we would expect, that the punishment simply does not fit the crime. They have asked the full bench to quash the sentence and declare the sentencing law invalid as it violates international human rights and the Australian constitution. They argue that it corrupts the separation of powers between the parliament, the courts and the executive as enshrined in the constitution. The appeal is a test case against the mandatory sentencing laws.

Unfortunately, it has come too late for 17-year-old Matthew Bradley of suburban Leanyer in Darwin. Matthew left prison on 15 July this year after serving 14 days imprisonment for stealing yo-yos and computer games valued at $579 from a toy shop. The Darwin Magistrate's Court was told that Matthew is an above average student at St John's College and a first offender who had paid full restitution for the thefts and damage and had personally apologised to the manager of the store. In fact, Matthew had confessed to his father, who had taken him and the stolen objects to the police. So Matthew did the right thing, showed genuine remorse, confessed to a crime the police had no idea he had perpetrated and society dealt with him for doing this by sending him to prison for 14 days.
I should point out that, to its credit, the Northern Territory News, despite the support in the territory, has consistently opposed the mandatory sentencing laws in its editorial columns.

BREAK.PARA: Matthew Bradley was joined in prison earlier this year by 20‐year‐old Edward Brown, who had pleaded guilty to stealing fuel worth $9 from a car. Magistrate James Hannan indicated that he intended to fine him for the offence but imposed the gaol sentence when reminded by the police prosecutor that he had no discretion other than to do so. I can understand many territorians like Mr McCosker accepting the arguments of local politicians for mandatory sentencing. Territorians are fed a constant diet of crime stories and court reportage often centres on what, on face value, sometimes appears to be light sentencing by the judiciary.

A recent pamphlet issued by the ruling Country Liberal Party claimed that the legislation was aimed at introducing tougher sentencing in the belief that this would act as a deterrent. The facts are that the weight of evidence both here and overseas shows that tougher sentencing or gaol terms does not act as a deterrent. But as Mr McCosker told a television interviewer last week, his support for mandatory sentencing was based on the view that going to gaol was something that happened to criminals not to ordinary people.

The statistics do not bear out claims of a territory crime wave. They do not take into account the population growth. There has been no serious public debate on the link between poverty, unemployment and crime. In my view, the overwhelming evidence shows that mandatory sentencing results in punishments which in many cases far outweighs the crime, as evidenced by the examples I have highlighted tonight.

This is a relatively new debate in Australia but it is not new in the United States, where mandatory sentencing was introduced in many states in the early 1970s. Imprisonment rates in America are now the highest in the world. It is interesting that the land of the free has the highest percentage of its citizens behind bars than any country in the world. But crime is not being reduced in the United States. Mandatory sentencing has been criticised all the way up the judicial chain in the US to the chairman of the US Sentencing Commission, Judge Richard Conaboy. He recently stated:

I don't think there's any system that invites more criticism than mandatory minimum sentencing, because you cannot fashion one sentence that fits every situation and every defendant and still take into consideration all of the aspects involved in every criminal act.
In fact, a number of American judges have quit the bench in protest rather than impose mandatory sentences, and many others refuse to hear cases where mandatory sentencing is involved.

Legal literature in the United States is littered with examples of the profound failure of these policies, which have seen the American prison population triple since 1980. The highest percentage of these increases in the prison population comprise young black Americans, mostly first time drug offenders. Perversely, in this same climate, many violent criminals are being released into the community to ease the overcrowding, with little or no supervision because of budget problems.

The Northern Territory already has the highest rate of imprisonment in Australia, with territorians imprisoned at the rate of three times the national average. There has been considerable press coverage on the already overcrowding problems at Berrimah Prison and there is a profound lack of juvenile facilities, with juveniles recently imprisoned in the new adult section of the Alice Springs Prison.

Quite apart from the inequities that I have outlined tonight, interestingly, not all property crime in the territory is subject to these mandatory sentencing laws. Curiously, shoplifting, which is often termed a middle-class crime, is exempt, as are a range of white‐collar crimes such as embezzlement and fraud. The territory suffers from a very high incidence of assault and sexual assault. In 1996 the incidence of assault in the territory was more than twice the national average, while the incidence of sexual assault was nearly twice the national average. Neither offence is subject to mandatory sentencing. It begs the question: is property more important than people?

The Northern Territory government has so far completely ignored criticisms from magistrates, including the Northern Territory's chief magistrate, and lawyers about the inherent inequities of these laws. However, I would hope that at some stage in the near future the government will review whether these laws have had any measurable effect on the property crime rate. The government must balance the community good against what are already individual cases of gross injustice. At that point, it should seriously consider wiping the slate clean and repealing this obnoxious legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who picked up today's Sydney Morning Herald to read the grim news that in the past 11 months six young women and teenage girls have been kidnapped or murdered or have disappeared along the New South Wales coastal highway would feel grief for the families and grave concern for society. There have been other like tragedies over the years and of late—for example, the missing 11‐year‐old boy from Western Australia—that make us think just how unsafe society has become.

SPEECH.PARA: Our concern is not just restricted to Australia. Who can forget the pictures that ricocheted around the world of the Belgium `house of horrors' where a paedophile ring was involved in the kidnapping, torture and murder of children as young as eight years old? At each tragedy a family suffers and a society is damaged. At each tragedy society fundamentally changes for the worse as once enjoyed freedoms are taken away, none less than life itself.

Therefore, if we were asked, `Is there something society can do to help rectify these seemingly irreversible changes?' we would answer yes. If we were told that there was a movie currently showing that graphically displays a story of kidnap, sexual abuse, torture and murder of adolescents in the style of the above incidents I have mentioned—indeed, a movie described as a handbook for the Mr Cruels of this world—would you believe that it should be banned? The answer from society would be yes.

I therefore bring to the Senate's attention the movie Salo, which is currently under review by the Film and Literature Board of Review. The review has been prompted by an application by the Queensland government to re‐ban the movie. The movie Salo was made in 1976 and banned in this country for some 17 years but was released into the mainstream theatres in 1993. The storyline begins with the kidnap of 16 adolescents in an Italian village, eight of each sex. For the remainder of the film, they are subjected to every form of violence, sexual humiliation and torture before being mass slaughtered in a most bizarre fashion. The movie has been condemned outright by every film critic of any note, being described as vile and a treat for sadists and psychopaths.

I make reference to the hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies in Sydney on Thursday, 5 August 1993 to try to encapsulate the depths and darkness of the movie Salo. The committee transcript reads that the movie:

Contains constant nudity, masturbation, forced sodomy, forced urolagnia, coprophagous, humiliation and degradation, anilingus, suicide, candlewax burns to breasts and male genitalia, a man's tongue cut off, an eye explicitly gouged out with a knife, a woman partially scalped, a boy's nipples branded with a hot iron, being forced to eat excreta, torture and killing during the "Cycle of Blood" canto. Naked male and female youths forced to behave as animals going on all fours to beg for food—eventually betraying their fellows in an attempt to survive, hanging, whipping, accompanied by raconteurs' stories based on offensive, fetishes and paedophilia, a woman's verbal accounts of sex experiences as a child and of matricide . . .

And there is much, much worse. Other descriptions are so graphic that I am prevented from citing them to the Senate. It is legitimate then to ask: according to whom and under what criteria was the movie Salo released into Australian society? In essence, the movie was released in 1993. The words of the Chairman of the then Film and Literature Review Board were that `adults in a free society ought to be allowed to see whatever they like'. He also said the movie has artistic merit even though the same chairman stated that the adolescents suffer sexual torment and sadistic humiliation of the extreme kind.

BREAK.PARA: Thankfully it is a very different Film and Literature Review Board in 1997 from what it was in 1993 when the ban was lifted on the movie. In fact, the board is in transition, with three new members soon to be appointed. The pending decision before the new review board will be to either redraw the line in the sand on censorship or continue to ride the pendulum of censorship towards the outer limits. I am sure that if the board were to use the community as their touchstone on this issue the movie would surely be re‐banned.

The time has come to say the censorship decisions in this country should not be underpinned by the motto `adults should be free to see whatever they like without regard to the cost to society'. For that matter, the time has come to bury that other reason the movie was released—artistic merit. This so often used catch phrase to release movies like Salo is an indulgent, sectional and narcissistic view and hurts the general good of society. Both tenets of faith are now discredited, particularly given the belief and evidence that a diet of violent and sexually abusive videos and movies will trigger the disturbed mind. Both tenets can no longer underpin our censorship philosophy to the exclusion of protecting a decent and accepted social standard. Therefore, each member of the Film and Literature Board of Review should vote to re‐ban Salo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last couple of days we have seen focus again on the important issues of the future of uranium mining in the Northern Territory. There have been two motions dealt with by this Senate, one late last week by Senator Bob Brown and another today by Senator Meg Lees. It is very interesting to note the importance of these issues. Naturally, both of those motions, coming from the green left field, certainly would be predictable as to what people are expecting from people in either the Greens or the Democrats and the position that they have historically taken and played with regard to the possibility of uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say from the side of politics where I stand that I totally support the open ing up of further uranium mines because I honestly believe that the environmental and Aboriginal considerations that seem to preoccupy so many people on the left have been well and truly dealt with and adequately controlled. Certainly, there is a commitment to making sure that the safeguards are properly in place and will be there for future generations and for the future economic development of the Northern Territory.

It is also important to look over the record on this issue of my Senate colleague from the Northern Territory, Senator Bob Collins. He has had a stance and a position that is well known and goes right back to 1986 at a famous Labor Party conference in Hobart where he took a position. Almost yearly since then he has made no secret of his support for more uranium mining as long as the price is right. Like me, he has often expressed concern about Aboriginal issues or environmental issues and how they stack up. It is also important to track the sort of record that Senator Collins has set. Let me put a couple of his comments back down. In 1992 Senator Collins said:
There's no secret about my position of support for the industry.
He also said:

It's whether those two mines should proceed irrespective of what the mineral is that they're producing and as I say particularly in the case of Jabiluka, not so much in the case of Koongarra which is a much smaller mine with a much shorter lifespan I mean it's a Nabarlek type deposit and I think frankly that Nabarlek demonstrated very well how you can engineer a mine and then restore the area very well afterwards with very little damage to the area, but in the case of Jabiluka you're talking about potentially a huge mine in the middle of and you would know that if you travel to the area as frequently as I do, in the middle of probably the most travelled tourist route in Kakadu; that is, the road from the Arnhem Highway to the East Alligator River crossing and the mine has got a life of 40 or 50 years depending on how much product you take out of it.
It is interesting to track this chronology. In December 1993 Senator Collins said:

The proximity of the two major deposits at Jabiluka and Koongarra to the Kakadu National Park will be I think the central issue in the debate. The fact that they are legally excised from the park, and always were, by the Fraser government when the park was created, they are located within Kakadu National Park and I think that will be the major focus for the debate.

In 1994 Senator Collins suggested a compromise which would allow two new mines in the Alligator River region of the Northern Territory but effectively cut out CRA's uranium leases in Western Australia. In the 1994 debate Senator Collins said:

I wish it worked like that in the market place and of course it doesn't no matter what commodity you're talking about. Each particular company has got its own contracts, its own connections around the world, its own arrangements.
More recently, in September 1995, Senator Collins said:

While there is a legitimate and peaceful‐purpose market for our uranium, then we should continue to be in the marketplace, and if the market indicates potential to open new mines, I believe there is a case for relaxing the three mines policy. But let me also make it clear—I am utterly opposed to what the French are doing in the Pacific.
More recently, in February 1996, Senator Collins said:
Additional mines would of course benefit the Territory economy, but the numbers people within the Labor Party have it right on this one.

Bringing that up to date in 1997, it is very important to look at the positions Senator Collins has taken in the voting. Last week, on the motion by Senator Bob Brown, Senator Collins sided with the Labor Party factional vote. Importantly, the final point of that motion called on the government to:
. . . proceed no further with the Jabiluka uranium proposal.
Where did Senator Collins vote? He voted along with the ayes on that motion and they were carried 34‐33. Shame on Senator Collins.

Then today, as I drew to your attention, Madam President, during the course of the debate on Senator Meg Lees's motion relating to Koongarra, Senator Collins was conspicuously absent from this chamber for the vote. He had sought a pair, as Senator Faulkner indicated in his interjection to me across the chamber—I think he used the words, `He's got a pair, you fool,' referring to me. I find that inexcusable when Senator Lees's motion set out to call on the government to now state clearly that it will not proclaim section 3 of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981.

So Senator Collins absented himself today. You can look back at the number of quotes and the issues of support he has given but he has now chosen, in an unfortunate way, a spineless absence from the Senate chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I ask you to withdraw that. You may not cast imputations on Senator Collins.

—I withdraw, Madam President, and refer to the senator's absence from the chamber today in the course of the vote when he had been here only several minutes before, speaking on a number of other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Thursday evening on a radio interview in Darwin the ABC reporter specifically asked about the then Bob Brown motion. He asked the question:
. . . you are expected to vote on party lines, but you do have the option to abstain from voting and seeking a pairing . . . don't you?
To which Senator Collins replied:
If I had been politically stupid enough to have done that, I would have given Bob Brown's silly anti uranium motion national publicity.

What has he done today? He has done exactly that to the `silly' Koongarra motion of today. Senator Collins has indicated that he has one standard—two bob each way, if you like—when he is acting on these important territory issues. He failed to vote with the Labor Party today on this important issue. He seems to have different arguments, different excuses each day.

Government members defeated that motion today. The Koongarra proposal is very important because that proposed agreement contains important benefits for traditional owners and the Aboriginal community, particularly in the areas of education and social advantages, if and when the mining project proceeds. It is peculiar and hypocritical in the extreme that Senator Collins has taken the action he did today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you need to withdraw that and perhaps phrase it differently. You should not refer to Senator Collins in the fashion you just did as you concluded.
—I withdraw.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 22 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister receive a copy of correspondence between a group of 20 major Australian and overseas environment groups and the World Heritage Committee, in Paris, asking that the World Heritage Kakadu National Park be listed as "World Heritage in Danger".
(2) Is the Minister aware that the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation wrote similar letters to the World Heritage Committee.
(3) What would be the effect on Australia's international environmental reputation if Kakadu National Park were to be listed as `World Heritage in Danger'.

(4) What will be the effect on Australia's international reputation, including as a tourist destination, if an additional uranium mine is established on a mineral lease excised from, but in every way contiguous with, the Kakadu National Park.

(5) What will be the effect on Australia's overseas reputation, including as a tourist destination, if an additional uranium mine is established on a mineral lease excised from, but in every way contiguous with, the Kakadu National Park if Kakadu's World Heritage status is declared to be `in danger'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I am aware that on 18 June 1997 the Mirrar Gundjehmi wrote to the World Heritage Bureau, which is the Executive of the World Heritage Committee, regarding this matter. I am currently not aware of whether the Australian Conservation Foundation has written in similar terms to the World Heritage Committee.

(3) No decision has been made by the World Heritage Committee to include Kakadu National Park in the List of World Heritage in Danger. In my view, there is no basis for suggesting that the Park be included on this list and there is no threat to Australia's international reputation. Australia will be reporting to the Committee that given the stringent processes in place to address any possible impacts on the World Heritage values of the Park, it does not consider that the values are under threat.

(4) I consider that the thorough way in which environmental assessment of the Jabiluka proposal was undertaken will in no way diminish Australia's international reputation. I do not believe that the Jabiluka mine will have an impact on Australia as a tourist destination given that there is no evidence of which I am aware to suggest that the Ranger uranium mine, which has been operating for some time within the same region, has had any impact on levels of tourist visitation.

I advised the Minister for Resources and Energy, in correspondence of 22 August 1997, that on the evidence available there appears to be no environmental issue which should prevent the proposed Jabiluka mine from proceeding provided the project is subject to stringent conditions relating to the biophysical, cultural and social significance of the environment associated with the mine.

In developing my recommendations to the Minister I was particularly mindful of Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention and the need to fully protect World Heritage values. I, and the Government, consider that with proper management, uranium mining outside the boundaries of Kakadu National Park will not have an adverse impact on the World Heritage values of the Park. On 8 October the Minister for Resources and Energy advised Energy Resources of Australia Ltd that he had endorsed my recommendations.
(5) See my answers to Questions (3) and (4).

(5) Australia's 1991 nomination of Kakadu National Park to the World Heritage List stated on page 84 that: `The cultural sites of Kakadu National Park exhibit six attributes that place them among the greatest bodies of sites in the world:

(7) The Report of the Sixteenth session of the World Heritage Committee (held December 1992) which considered the 1991 renomination of Kakadu National Park, commended the Australian authorities `for concluding a 10-year program to extend this park and for the exemplary management operation at the Park'. The Government remains committed to the management of Kakadu in a manner that protects all aspects of its World Heritage values, including the `living cultural tradition that continues today'.

The Government recently sponsored, jointly with the Northern Territory Government and Energy Resources of Australia, a comprehensive and independent study of the social impact of development on Aboriginal communities in the Kakadu region. The study produced a Community Action Plan to both mitigate impacts and to realise the opportunities that Kakadu represents for reflecting the meaning of a reconciled Australian society.

The joint management arrangement for Kakadu National Park, between the Commonwealth the park's traditional owners, is one of the success stories for reconciliation. Joint management and the protection of Kakadu's World Heritage values will be further developed in the life of the next Kakadu National Park Plan of Management, which I am currently considering.

(8) As I have indicated in my answer to Question 6, Kakadu National Park is inscribed on the World Heritage List for natural criteria (ii), (iii) and (iv). Each of these criteria is addressed in turn:
Criterion (ii) Outstanding examples representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his natural environment
Ongoing geological processes;

The area encompassed by the Kakadu National Park has experienced considerable change during a relatively short geological period. Extensive mangrove swamps developed about 6500 years ago, at the time the sea reached its current level. Over the next 1000 years, increasing sedimentation effectively choked the mangroves, resulting in the formation of flood plains and tidal river channels. The Magela flood plain developed as recently as 1300 years ago. These processes were driven predominantly by sea-level changes. Geological processes continue today, with the coast of the park growing at the relatively fast rate of 20- 30 centimetres per year. The effects on these geological processes caused by the tailings repositories, which cover approximately 0.005% of the area of Kakadu National Park, will be negligible over all time scales.
Biological evolution;

Unless it is demonstrated to the Supervising Scientist that an alternative design of tailings repository is at least as protective of the environment, all tailings will be returned to mine pits. The inherent stability of a pit renders the risk of a catastrophic failure of the tailings repository negligible. Thus the credible pathways for transport of contaminants to the biosphere are via groundwater and erosion. Measures will be taken to reduce groundwater contamination to inconsequential levels by sealing aquifers that intersect the pits and possibly by the use of a permeable envelope which will divert groundwater flow around the tailings in the event of seals failing. Both techniques will be subject to ongoing research and development to tailor them to the site specific requirements of the Ranger lease.

Minimisation of contaminant transport via erosion will be achieved by the capping design for the tailings repositories. The capping over the tailings in the pits will have a design life of at least 200 years and a structural life of at least 1000 years. This means that the capping will perform its required function without maintenance or renovation for at least 200 years, and will continue to perform its basic function, albeit at a reduced level of efficiency, for at least 1000 years. These criteria ensure that there will be no effect on the Kakadu ecosystem within the first 200 years.

The tailings will effectively replace the uranium ore which was present in the pits prior to mining. After 200 years, there may be a gradual release of radioactive material in a manner similar to the natural processes which affected the undisturbed uranium ore prior to mining. The effective half life of tailings is less than 0.002% (or one-fifty thousandth) of uranium ore, resulting in a much reduced radiological burden in the very long term. Between 200 years and several tens of thousands of years after mine decommissioning, the envisaged release of radioactive materials from the tailings repository will be similar to that which would have occurred if the ore had not been mined. After this period, the much shorter half life of the tailings when compared to uranium ore (77,000 years compared with 4.5 billion years) is likely to result in a release rate less than that which would have occurred if the ore had not been mined.

The ecosystem of the Kakadu region has evolved over the millennia in an environment with enhanced radiation levels. The uranium tailings are not expected to alter the biological evolution of the Kakadu ecosystem in the short or long term.
Man's interaction with the natural environment

The tailings repositories will have no impact on sacred sites or rock art, and will be designed and constructed in a manner such that Aboriginal people may safely undertake traditional activities in the area. Access to the tailings repositories is likely to be restricted for a period of several years after decommissioning to allow for continued monitoring and assessment. However, after this initial period, it is likely that the area will be incorporated within the Kakadu National Park. Aboriginal people will then be free to access the area in an identical manner to any other part of the park, and the impact of the tailings on man's interaction with the natural environment will be nil.
Criterion (iii) Unique, rare or superlative natural phenomena, formations or features or areas of exceptional natural beauty.

The tailings repositories will have no impact on the escarpment or other outstanding geological formations of Kakadu. Nor, as discussed in relation to Criterion (ii), will the tailings damage the ecosystems of the flood plains or eucalypt forests. The entire mine site, including the tailings repositories will be landscaped and revegetated with native species, returning it to a state congruous with the pre-mining environment. In less than 50 years, the mine site is likely to be indistinguishable in most respects from the surrounding areas.

Criterion (iv) The most important and significant habitats where threatened species of plants and animals of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science and conservation still survive.

As discussed in relation to Criterion (ii), the tailings will not impact upon the surrounding ecosystem for at least the first 200 years after mine decommissioning. Sometime later than 200 years post mine decommissioning, there may be a slow release of radioactive material into the environment mirroring that which would have occurred if the ore had not been mined. This release is not expected to have any significant deleterious effects on the local habitats. In the very long term, the noticeably shorter effective half life of tailings compared to uranium ore will result in a significantly lower radiological burden to the local habitat.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: In each of the past 10 years:
(1) How many phone taps were sought and how many were authorised in Australia by: (a) Com‐
monwealth authorities; (b) State and Territory authorities; and (c) how many of the taps resulted in convictions.
(2) (a) Which police, security or other organisations or individuals sought taps; and (b) how many were authorised for each organisation.

(3) (a) What is the technical nature of the taps that have been allowed; (b) were warrants issued for listening devices other than those involving telecommunications; if so what was the nature of those devices.
(4) (a) Have any members of State, Territory or Commonwealth parliaments been the target of taps; and (b) were any journalists so targeted.
(5) How many listening devices are currently warranted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: Introductory remarks.

It has been the policy of successive Australian governments not to comment on operational intelligence matters. I intend to maintain that policy. Consequently, the following answers do not include data concerning interception or listening device warrants issued to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO).

The amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 that permit the National Crime Authority (NCA) and a declared `eligible authority' of a State to apply for an interception warrant did not come into operation until 1 September 1988. Those amendments also significantly extended the classes of offences for which warrants may be issued. Before that date, an interception warrant for law enforcement purposes could be sought only by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for the investigation of narcotic offences punishable as provided by section 235 of the Customs Act 1901. Consequently, statistics on interception warrants issued to law enforcement agencies during the year 1987/88 are not included in the reply.

A report concerning telephone interception warrants issued to law enforcement agencies during the year 1996/97 is currently being prepared. The report will be tabled in Parliament in accordance with section 104 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
1 (a) Commonwealth authorities—number of applications made for Part VI warrants and warrants issued.
1 (b) State and Territory authorities—number of applications made for Part VI warrants and warrants issued.
1 (c) Number of offences in respect of which convictions were recorded where lawfully obtained information1 was given in evidence in the related prosecution.

1 The term `lawfully obtained information' is defined in subsection 6E(1) of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 as information obtained by intercepting, otherwise than in contravention of subsection 7(1), a communication passing over a telecommunications system.
2 (a) Agencies/persons permitted to apply for warrants1 under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
(i) Part III warrants
The Director-General of Security is permitted to request the Attorney-General to issue a Part III warrant.
(ii) Part VI warrants
An application for a Part VI warrant may be on behalf of the following agencies (together with the date from which the agency has been able to make an application):

Australian Federal Police
Victoria Police—from 28 October 1988
New South Wales Police Service—from 30 January 1989
South Australia Police—from 10 July 1991
Western Australian Police Service—from 11 July 1997
Other law enforcement agencies
National Crime Authority—from 1 September 1988
New South Wales Crime Commission—from 30 January 1989
Independent Commission Against Corruption—from 30 January 1989
2 (b) Number of warrants issued to law enforcement agencies under Part VI of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
2 The difference between Part II and Part VI warrants is explained in the answer to Question 3.
3 (a) Telecommunications interception

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 does not specify the nature of a device that may be used under a warrant. A warrant authorises the agency to which it is issued to intercept communications made to or from a service. Intercepting a communication means listening to or recording, by any means, that communication in its passage over a telecommunications system without the knowledge of the person making the communication (subsection 6(1)).
(i) Part III warrants

The Attorney-General, on receipt of a request by the Director-General of Security, may issue a warrant allowing ASIO to intercept telecommunications to obtain intelligence relating to security (section 9) or to obtain foreign intelligence (section 11A). In addition, the Director-General of Security may issue a warrant in emergencies and for a short term (section 10).
(ii) Part VI warrants
Only certain judges, referred to in the Act as `eligible Judges', may issue warrants authorising interceptions for law enforcement purposes.

In deciding whether to issue a warrant, the Judge must be satisfied about certain matters set out in section 45 (class 1 offences) or section 46 (class 2 offences). The principal matters which the Judge is required to consider are: the availability of alternative methods of investigating the offence; and, in the case of class 2 offences, the gravity of the conduct being investigated and the degree of interference with the privacy of any person. Class 1 and class 2 offences are defined in subsection 5(1) and section 5D respectively.

Where an application for a warrant includes a request that the warrant authorise entry on prem ises, the Judge is also required to be satisfied that it would be impracticable or inappropriate to intercept communications by less intrusive means (section 48).
Legislative amendments made in 1993 permit State agencies to execute their own warrants; except that a section 48 warrant can be executed only by an authorised member of the AFP.
(iii) Interceptions by police in emergencies

Subsections 7(4) and (5) of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 permit the AFP and `declared' State police forces to intercept a communication without a warrant in specified emergency situations. As soon as practicable after making an interception under these provisions, the police force must apply for a warrant.
3 (b) Listening devices
(i) Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 (the ASIO Act)

A `listening device' is defined in the ASIO Act to mean any instrument, device or equipment capable of being used, whether alone or in conjunction with any other instrument, device or equipment, to record or listen to words, images, sounds or signals (section 22).

The ASIO Act permits the Attorney-General, upon receipt of a request by the Director-General of Security, to issue a warrant authorising ASIO to use a listening device in relation to a particular person to obtain intelligence relevant to security (section 26). The Attorney-General must be satisfied, among other things, that that person is engaged in, or is reasonably suspected by the Director-General of Security of being engaged in, or being likely to engage in, activities prejudicial to security. There is provision for the Director-General of Security to issue a warrant in emergencies (section 29).

In addition, the Attorney-General may, in specified circumstances, authorise ASIO to use a listening device for the purpose of performing its function under paragraph 17(1)(e) of the ASIO Act (section 27A).
(ii) Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (the AFP Act)

The AFP Act provides for an `eligible Judge' to issue a warrant authorising the AFP to use a listening device in relation to a particular person or particular premises to assist inquiries in relation to the commission, or likely commission of a class 1 general offence or a class 2 general offence by that person (section 12G). Those classes of offences are defined at section 12B of the AFP Act.

A `listening device' is any instrument, device or equipment capable of being used, whether alone or in conjunction with any other instrument, device or equipment to record or listen to spoken words (section 12B).
(iii) Customs Act 1901 (the Customs Act)

Division 1A of Part XII of the Customs Act provides for the issue of listening devices by a judge to a Commonwealth law enforcement agency (that is, the AFP and the NCA) to investigate a narcotics offence in the meaning of that Act. The definition of a `listening device' at section 219A of the Customs Act is the same as the definition in the AFP Act given above.
(Note: The use of listening devices by State police and the Northern Territory Police, is controlled by State and Territory legislation.)
4. It has been the policy of successive Australian governments not to comment on operational intelligence and law enforcement matters.

In addition, subsection 63(2) of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 prohibits the communication of `designated warrant information' which includes information about the existence or non-existence of a warrant or any other information that is likely to enable the identification of a person specified in a warrant.
5. I cannot comment on the number of listening device warrants currently in force as this is an operational matter.
However, the total number of listening device warrants issued to Commonwealth law enforcement agencies during the most recent two years were:
a. Australian Federal Police: 1995/96—375; 1996/97—368.
b. National Crime Authority: 1995/96—107; 1996/97—105.
